pros: Amazing Pay and Benefits, Great Accommodations for disabled, Strong military recruitment pathways, extremely charitable for social impact organizations and the community. Depending on team you get on Work Culture can be great.
cons: Training has been non-existent for many of us, Computer Based Training covers big ticket items, but day to day duties is barely touched by direct managers or peers. Many learn as you go. Acronym Soup, and the language used means different things across different groups within the organization which causes confusion. Work Life balance can be breached because of Fire Drills and excess meetings. There are excess meetings with no breaks during the work day which means everyone on calls are doing work during meetings to meet deadlines and are half engaged in the calls.

review: Not Your Average Small Town Bank
pros: Good benefits like; retirement plan offered, 4 months maturnity leave, heath insurance, etc.
cons: Constant manager oberservation, your obligations include sharing digital services like the WF mobile app, mobile deposit, Zelle, etc., with almost EVERY customer you help. Another obligation is to try to refer our customers to sit with personal bankers for financial reviews. You can't just be an "order taker" with this job, they expect you to ask the customer questions to uncover possible financial needs. So you have to get comfortable asking these questions and also get good multitasking cause this is expected to be done while your completing their transactions.

review: Great to their employees, lousy to their customers...
pros: if you have any sort of disability or require special working conditions, even to the extent that you need to take several days off a month because of your mental/physical health, Wells Fargo is the place for you. All you need is for a doctor to fill out a 6 page form stating what your condition is and what accommodations you require. With said documentation, Wells will bend over backwards to accommodate your mental/physical condition, as well as any situations that arise within your family . Whether it's only being able to work 6 hours a shift, needing to take emergency, extended family leave for a non life-threatening situation or being allotted several excused absences per month because of a chronic medical condition, Wells Fargo will adapt the schedule, the work environment, to the individual's needs instead of trying to force them into an untenable work situation which would result in an unhappy, underproductive employee who wouldn't last very long.
cons: They are a large. greedy corporate machine that sees numbers and not customers. I spend a lot of time teaching people about their lines of credit because the more they know, the harder it is for the bank to take money from them. I'm not allowed to tell them what ALL their options are or I get into trouble, but if no one tells them something is possible, how will they know to ask? I feel like I often work with the customer AGAINST the company! I just want to be able to offer the customers the best options possible without getting into trouble.

review: Internal Audit is a nightmare at Wells
pros: Pay is very competitive and benefits are good
cons: I quit Wells in 2020. Internal Audit at Wells has had a MAJOR exodus of people leaving in 2019-2021 because of several reasons. You have to log all your time and meet productivity requirements. Meetings, trainings, donât count. You have to somehow reach a 96% efficiency. Itâs kind of like being in work prison. There is little to no chance of advancement. You have to invest years here before you are even considered. Favoritism abounds here. The audit process and systems are so complicated And convoluted, youâre going to be confused 99% of the time. Everything is always changing. Processes , templates, methodologiesâ¦.everything. All the senior management are so worried about career advancement they undertake projects to improve things. That creates a HUGE mess. The company is so big and there are so many different lines of business itâs always chaotic and crazy. Too much to know and too little time focusing on actual audit work. Roles are never defined and you never know what you are responsible for. Too much work and not enough down time. You canât reach out and contact people. You will get reprimanded for contacting the wrong people and asking a question. Everyone is kept fearful of senior management.

review: Good benefits and pay for a considerably easy job.
pros: Benefits are good, pay is decent and after past misconduct lawsuits, Wells Fargo has placed high priority on great working conditions for employees. Including, employee resources, workplace accommodations, zero tolerance for retaliation and work-life balance.
cons:
Opportunities for career advancements are dictated by an organizational growth chart which may require you to hold an intermediary position you don't want prior to being placed in the role you do want. 

Often times, those roles must first be held in low demand regions which could require you to relocate in order to advance. 

The only other workaround is to gain endorsement from higher ups which can often require a lot of sucking up. If you aren't prepared for that type of corporate culture than you are better off rising through the ranks by jumping into higher roles with competitors. 

(My experience is limited to that of the Retail Banking Sector, I cannot speak for others)

review: A Day in the Life at Wells Fargo
pros: You get to meet a ton of new people, depending on your location. Can be a very fun environment.
cons: You have to deal with irate customers, must have a great attitude. Also, you have to constantly take learning assessments but can only do it in between customers. This is good if you're at a slow location, bad if you're at a busy location.

review: Decent First Job in Finance - Not a Place to Stay
pros: Learn how one of the biggest banks in the US works. Decent pay. Good benefits
cons: Company does not care about its employees much. Says it values diversity and inclusion but really only appreciates and accepts ideas that are consistent with their own.

pros: 401k match up to 6% , job security in the fraud area, co workers are nice, work from home currently
cons: There is a plan to send everyone back to the office in January even though no one on my team wants to work in office and cases on the rise in AZ and productivity at home is better than in office. Wells Fargo does not spend ANY money on recognition or making employees feel valued. It's really up to the manager that you get as to whether they will make you feel valued. It's turn and burn and the upper managers don't seem to care about work life balance and burn out and people quitting. New employees are not sent home to work. The old Wells fargo years ago had company picnics, Holiday parties, fun team meetings with lunch and team builders. Sadly, all of that is gone.

review: Can't make decisions; need to revamp technology
pros:
- I worked with people who really wanted to do the best thing for the customers
- People who rally understood how the business works
- Scale and size to make an industry changing models
- Did things that
cons:
- Technology and tools are way behind; and trying to get permission to adopt not even cutting edge (Slack for example) is impossible
- Someone makes a mistake, add a process to make sure it does not happen again. Problem is you end up with way too much overhead
- Risk trumps literally anything
- Can't make decisions - took 3 plus years to choose a public cloud vendor AND that decision was 180 degrees the opposite of the direction the year before. 
- If you worked for Wells before 2018, your chances to get promoted are almost none. New management chain is 100% Chase based.

review: Current Employee; Formal Loyal Team Member
pros: Benefits are top notch. 6% matching 401k, four months maternity/PATERNITY leave paid, etc. Diversity and inclusion is a huge focus. Paid time off is fantastic even starting out. Plus for my role all federal holidays.
cons:
Does not value loyal employees. Consistently get lowballed for promotion raises and yearly increases are a joke. Have missed 3 of my 5 due to minimum wage increasing. Meaning I made below the new minimum and they just put me at the minimum with every NEW employee. Itâs a corporate game.
ALSO since 2016 there has been a major shift from preferring internal promotions to overzealous preference for external hires. Itâs over the top. I know we are changing for the better but external does not equal change, internals can bring change too.

Iâve also experienced a lot of internal changes in management and position within a very short timeframe. pros: You can work as much as you want, the more you work the more opportunities you get to build your pipeline, and the larger the pipeline the larger your income potential. Average salary is around 70-80k, but if you are a professional sales person with experience in the industry or a well-rounded understanding of personal finance, the ability to make 120-200k is possible and there are many people doing it here. This is a centralized role meaning you take inbound calls for half of your work day to get your leads, you donât have to source any of your own. If you work out of a branch or mortgage office, you donât get that luxury.
cons: Compensation structure in supporting roles isnât as competitive so you donât always get the highest quality processors and support personnel, which creates more work for you as a consultant.

review: long work hours, tough work schedule
pros: none, you can find a better job else where. I quit the job even though I didn't have anything lined up and didn't qualify for unemployment because I quit; that's how bad it was.
cons:
everyone I knew worked long hours. The rookies were up to midnight most days, working on Saturdays as well. A couple of times I had to work through the night to complete cases; others said they've done the same.

People worked on their cases even on their day off and unless you were taking a long vacation, caseload was added even when you were taking days off. I dissuaded people from working there.

Had to summarize every type of transaction, bring in other client accounts if they were involved in suspicious activity. Limited KYC information. Manager always assumed that I was making the cases more complicated; had to argue that the previous investigator didn't do their job correctly and didn't add in all suspects.

review: Big corporation - but our managers show too much favoritism
pros: The benefits were/are very good - and the working conditions were nice.
cons:
There is too much discretion given to managers. I've seen managers reward "favorite" employees with special privileges -- yet these same manager(s) have denied reasonable requests using "policy" as an excuse. Therefore, all employees are NOT treated equally.

There is also too much pressure on tellers to push mobile services and to set up banker (sales) meetings - rather than just providing excellent customer service and listening to the customer's expressed needs.

Great benefits became HUGE deductibles. Management hides from issues, people, responsibilities. They don't want people that can build the business, develop teams, and turn around unprofitable units. That means during their 20 years they haven't done their jobs. Makes them look bad, and they are only there to insure their own paycheck... Not the company's growth or the great people in the front lines of customer sales and service. Many legacy peers support this to retain their own bureaucracies.

review: Everything is good but the pay
pros:
- Great health benefits. I believe there are about 8 programs to choose from. Excellent dental insurance. 
- The company generally keeps up with its equipment/software updates. The systems work propertly most of the time. 
- Competent, knowledgeable, and helpful coworkers. 
- Depending on your team/department, some managers really do develop their team. You have lots of learning opportunities.
- Many positions are hourly and provide good work/life balance. In some positions you can work 6 AM to 2:30 PM, if you're into that kind of stuff.
cons:
- The pay is one HUGE con. For many positions, the gross will not exceed 60k/year. The company will do anything to low ball you. There is always an explanation for obscenely low salaries. I've talked to people who's been wit Wells Fargo for 10 years or more and they stated that their salary is $52k/year. How is this sustainable/fair/competitive? The benfits are great, but they don't pay the bills. Also, if you get a raise, it will be around $1,000. And they won't negotiate. 
- Emphasis on the team in India. Often times if a team needs to fill in an open position, they will be told to hire someone in India. The difference in the time zones creates weird schedules on both ends.

review: Not the same company 3 years ago
pros: The stars are given to the company 3 years ago. It was a decent company with great people.
cons: Since new management (CEO) being onboard in 2019, the company has been turned around in a disruptive way. One example is that the company no longer hires risk Management professionals in California, regardless internal or external. It shuts off the doors to all California employees. Morale is low. Wells Fargo has been headquartered in SF for more than 150 years, and the action is very brutal and unfair to CA employees.

- Work retaliation

pros: There are always nice people in every job - folks who actually want to do a good job and be helpful.
cons:
If you want to be a eunuch then Wells Fargo is the place for you! While they present an attractive image in their mission and value statements, the reality is quite different - the majority of people you interact with are dispirited, disillusioned, mentally exhausted, and unmotivated. They are just treading water until it is time to retire.

I have been in business for 27 years and worked previously at Wells over 20 years ago. The amazing thing is they have not grown as an organization in those past two decades. The same dominance-based structure is firmly in place - one that withholds information from the employees in order to allow the managers to feel they are in control. Perhaps they believe they are adding value? It is a pretty sad state of affairs when territorialism and protecting your image are the main goals of the so-called leadership (in actuality, 'rudderless ship' is the best analogy). Saul van Beurden is very compelling and seems open minded and helpful - but the reality is you will never work for anyone like him. Your managers will be barely literate and emotionally stunted individuals who never say 'Thank You' or acknowledge your work ('No, folks - a paycheck really is not enough!').

Purportedly they are implementing Agile but it is really Agile in name only; the teams are completely disempowered and unable to plan given the shifting requirements and paucity of information. Again, it feels like this is a control issue where the many levels of weak management don't want to face their approaching obsolescence.

Sad state of affairs - so many people wasting their lives working in meaningless job. It is a paycheck - and that is the best you can hope for at WF.

review: Depending on the Person you are...
pros: Benefits and 401k are great
cons: Everything else...poor community within organization. Zero engagement with team members. You won't get to know your coworkers beyond the work. Pay is relatively low for the amount of work/stress comes from the job. Company made well over 3x their annual revenue in 2021 and were sticklers when it came to yearly raises. Managed the COVID stuff very poorly and this stems from upper-upper management. You will be a number here. If you need team orientation, this gig is not for you.

pros: *Access to a wide variety of investment options and the ability to access banking products for clients that are interested.
cons:
*Incredible waste and overhead from redundant layers of management. Many could be fired tomorrow and employees wouldn't notice. There are also unnecessary job positions like "productivity consultants" that do nothing except forward e-mails with information that's already available to us.
*Technology is awful. My computer constantly freezes for the most basic functions like minimizing a window. I've had several computers and essentially they are so cheap they can't run our software efficiently. Things that should be done in a few minutes end up taking much longer.
*Advisors have pay cut almost every year except when the bank had the scandal and they couldn't afford to lose more Advisors.
*They only care about high net worth clients and nobody else. 
*Advisors are unable to discount trades beyond 5% without paying for it themselves.
*Back office support is extremely incompetent, inefficient, and has no accountability.

review: Be CAREFUL! Quid Pro Quo on salary negotiations from contractor to full-time.
pros:
Nice coworkers and teams below middle management (Manager band)
Upper management is really attentive and great people (Leaders and higher)
cons: I initially took a contract offer from a middle manager within a growing part of the bank. I did great work and so she offered me a full time role. She promised that my current salary would match the full time. She waited 9 months from verbal offer to post my role, and then she left for a new team. The new manager (35 years with bank) offered me a 40% pay-cut. Said he spoke to the other manager and that's the best the bank could do. I wanted to stay a contractor but my time limit (I think it's 2 years) was coming due, and needed a job. So I took it with 30% pay cut. This bank left a terrible taste in my mouth.

pros:
-Hires and supports a diverse workforce - all ages, races, sexual orientations, veterans

cons:
Will try to be objective as possible, these are my 20+ year experience and observations from a direct role in infrastructure tech to interacting with software developers, business system consultants, tech/project managers and support desks. The order below is random, no priority. 

#01 Poor business ethics. Any job working in the financial sector, especially larger institutions, requires the ability to ignore certain realities.

#02 Double standards. This ties in with #01. Tech is required, as they should, to not have any unauthorized changes, not lose their laptop, follow processes accordingly, etc. Threats of termination for being out of compliance were directly relayed to me and my peers on the first day by our new vice president when WF acquired our smaller company. In my opinion, any infraction we do whether intended or not is not nearly as damaging as the questionable business practices executed by using the systems we are employed to keep running. 

#03 No clear paths for career advancement. Managers do not offer any career support; they are constantly worried/distracted about keeping their jobs; spend a lot of time in the trenches alongside their direct reports instead of being empowered to manage. 

#04 Unclear hiring practices. Sometimes the budget only allows hiring contractors, or hiring overseas, etc. Each time it can prevent internal candidates from advancement. This has affected me personally, where I ended up guiding a lower qualified new person in a higher role that I applied for.

#05 Little to no pay raise/promotions within internal role. As a lead, I went over 10 years without a promotion and when it did happen, it was a blanket promotion.

#06 Toxic working culture. Starts with management and goes on down. Rudeness on calls, hang ups, lack of accountability, no response to emails or chats, lack of professionalism with colleagues when requesting improvements. High performers will find themselves boxed out and being questioned for trying to go above and beyond. 

#07 Internal re-orgs take too much time. Tied to #05, if roles and responsibilites shift from one team to another, there isn't a clear path to make it happen. Some workers and managers choose to remain doing legacy functions, some do a hybrid of legacy/new functions. Anyone who wants to move forward will struggle with the pace of play.

#08 Lack of using existing data. Management can request data be manually inputted in a separate system when that data is already attainable and more accurate via existing databases. Workers then have to manage multiple systems.

#09 Overuse of email for work requests. Email is well past its prime. Internally there are a few widely known systems of record where requests can be submitted with built-in tracking, notifications, metrics, etc.

#10 Confusing bureaucratic processes. Typical of any big company, a lot of work is subject to interpretation. Catch someone on a nice day, they'll help you avoid time-consuming order and approval forms. Going normal routes to request work is quite the journey and takes time away from interesting or more pressing tech work.

#11 Reactionary unstructured approach to work. If an event happens, say a rare power outage at a critical site, it can derail all other important projects and force everyone to focus on disaster recovery in the moment. It isn't a problem to shift focus to respond to current conditions, it is a problem to shift focus without any strategy.

#12 Unclear roles and responsibilities. It is good to have minimal boundaries in day to day work, as long as it is understood what your primary role is and what is expected of you. 

#13 Aging workforce is terribly slow to accept change, regardless of complexity.

#14 Skills advancement/training is poor. There is an expansive library of internal courses with a cumbersome interface to use; not all courses are available at certain times, not all are free.

#15 Agile methodologies lack vision and support. For those who aren't software developers, Agile is a major change to how you approach work each day. Some think Agile means "just get it done fast, clean it up later", instead of appreciating it as a formal method for efficiency. 

#16 The worst is always behind, better days ahead right? If I was interviewing today, this is what I would ask and would want to know details.

pros: Good benefits, Paid time off
cons: No career advancement as promised for PB1. No increase in pay for PB1 to do both roles 2 jobs)(banker and teller). Not enough training time given to pb1s to take on teller role. Staffing issues especially when PB1 is worked more as a teller than a banker. Relationship bankers get paid more to do less and actually do less to sit in their offices and wait on referrals from pb1s and tellers. No consideration of pb1 in regards to whether they want to do the job of a teller just mandatory change with no pay increase to do 2 jobs. Overworked and underpaid. Relationship bankers treat pb1 as secretaries to set them up for referrals while having no incentives or pay for pb1s to refer and branch management is behind the process. Branch management doesn't follow up on creating an teamwork environment as far as stopping other people from taking places of authority that HAVE NOT been placed in authority. (Relationship banker). Branch management just let's things slide instead of confronting issues with relationship banker. Company tries to control people's choices. No incentives, appreciation or recognition for loyal employees. Company tends to choose customers over employees. Anyone in the role below a relationship banker has no appealing attraction, incentive, or bonus to want to stay (in one person's opinion.)

pros:
Wells wants to be an inclusive company that treats its customers and employees appropriately. In practice, they do accomplish that on a daily basis.

I actually think a lot of the regulatory scrutiny is overblown (show me a big bank that does not have problems). Yes, the bank screwed up. But, they have been through a few CEOs, a CFO, and most of their Board in the mean time. 
 Oh, and they fired 5,000+ people and paid billions in fines. They can't seem to get out of the spotlight. It is easier for the regulators/politicians to kick a bank that is already on the ground than it is to scrutinize another bank.
cons:
The risk controls that have been put in place are excessive. They make almost any job at the bank harder than it should be.

I would also question some of the strategic decisions by management. Just a small example. Wells sold its 401k administration business to Prudential. Then, they selected a different vendor (Empower) to administer their 401k plan going forward. Empower does not have any electronic connectivity to Wells Fargo Advisors (apparently Wells is one of the few brokers that does not have electronic connectivity to Empower). Wells sells this business to a vendor that they themselves are not willing to use going forward, and then they pick an alternative that can't easily roll 401k accounts over their internal brokerage operation. Who makes these decisions?

review: My Investment Banking Internship at Wells Fargo Gave Me Great Experience But It w
pros:
- Internship pays well and overtime bonuses are great

- Investment banking interns will get a lot of live deal experience over the summer. I got to do work for 4 major industries

- Believable experience. You will feel like a seasoned banker by the end of the summer given the exposure

- Despite the demanding nature of the job, your technical skills will improve significantly

- Great way to transition into the financial services industry. You will learn about many aspects of the financial services industry.
cons:
- Interns not treated well. Full-time analysts and vice presidents (VP's) disrespected me throughout the summer. Most people are easily angered due to the demanding, high-stress nature of the job.

- Mentorship was present but lacking. I only got a hold of my mentors a couple of times throughout the entire summer

- Interns not given sufficient time to work on the summer project. We were told deal work takes priority of EVERYTHING but were forced to scramble to put our projects together. This was frustrating because the project held a significant amount of weight during our end-of-summer review

- The hours for this job are insane. There were many nights where I only got a couple hours of sleep. Interns don't get special treatment and are expected to work with full-time analysts through the night if necessary. Make sure you learn how to maintain/improve your health & well-being because this job is a time suck. Whatever time isn't used for sleep must be used for working out and managing your mental health. Do not apply for this internship if you think you'll be able to enjoy a decent work-life balance

review: Good to gain experience, great benefits. Out of touch upper management
pros: The benefits are decent enough with multiple health plans to choose from to fit your type of needs. Good time off per year with gaining more per year and capping out after a few years. Flexible management with time off and moving team members around to cover shortages. Semi-decent schedules. Tough to get
cons:
Terrible out of touch top level management:
Changed sick policy during covid and will be forcing employees to return to work in office. It felt as though work from home was dangled in front of employees to make them work harder and regularly perform above expectations. Not only are they recalling ALL teammates that worked from home during covid they are also asking those whom were hired as remote before the pandemic to start coming into the office all in the name of efficiency and collaboration. National statistics show that productivity is up. Yet Charlie is trying to get rid of it again. When this was attempted at BNY it caused a huge uproar. Now he is repeating history at wells Fargo. Covid has shown that work from home can be a valuable tool to employees. to take it away on the premise of something that is not true is wrong.

pros: Great benefits; Can make very generous commission checks but you will have to hustle for your commissions and submit clean loan files if you expect your loans to fund. If you get into a Bilingual queue be ready to spend long hours on the phones guiding customers on electronic signatures and how to submit documents. You do get paid more per hour and per loan if you are in a bilingual position. Management is very supportive. Always available if you need additional coaching.
cons: lots of micromanaging, listening in on phone calls if you are not performing up to their standards. This is a sales position therefore, you will have to be constantly on the phones trying to get people to apply for a loan. There is a set inbound/outbound time and you have to remain within adherence. Will have to work overtime. Sometimes OT is mandatory. Will have to take ongoing course work to remain compliant. Get 30 min lunches. Will have to work at least one Saturday per month.

Team managers are a joke. They are 30 year olds who have no leadership skills nor do they truly care about the concerns of their team. Itâs all metrics.
You must stay in your position for one year so this limits career growth and opportunity. This should be maybe 6 months. There is so much talent wasted because of this.

pros: Stable Job, stable benefits, PTO and job protection

For example I train people on a daily and one of the individuals that I trained was promoted before me and Iâve been with the department for over two years, that person has been with the department for less than one year. I donât know if it is a race issue or not (Iâm black and the person promoted is Caucasian) but it feels that way. Unfortunately my career with the company has been at a standstill and has not yet progressed despite how much work and effort I put in each day so as a result I will be looking outside of the company for my next employment role.

review: Poor company culture/work environment, NOT recommended
pros: The only positive is that there is good salary and benefits
cons:
Senior and executive management is horrible, they lack direction and seem powerless. Likely because there are too many management layers in general.

There are still residual effects of the sales scandal, and there is an overly aggressive risk focus. So much so that they make decisions based on fear of scrutiny rather than good business sense.

"Innovation" doesn't really exist there, even though they have groups with that name in it. Projects move at a snails pace there.

review: Can be a learning experience with some limitations
pros:
Benefits which include Dental, Vision, and Medical
Growth Entry level Teller job can branch out to many positions
Good Training Proper training and opportunity as a rookie
Easy to balance life and work as a 30 hr Full-time Bank Teller
cons:
Inconsistent procedure requirements throughout management. Meaning on manager might not care if you follow a procedure and might even encourage to go around it. While other managers will ruin your day if you didn't follow procedure. Teller training is good but when tellers started getting more responsibilities that bankers did, training could have been better.
During the pandemic the CEO informed the company that they are working on providing more diversity. He provided statics that only 8% of Leadership are African American and will work on doubling that number in the next 2-5 years.
Wells Fargo recently laid off many branch managers, bankers, and tellers during the pandemic and after. While also demoting business bankers and lead tellers.
30 hr Full-time Bank Teller $18 hourly wage is not enough for a living wage in San Diego, California.

pros: They had good benefits package. I think it's one of the better banks to work for, however, I joined right after their scandal and quit two years before the pandemic.
cons: Sales. Sales. More sales. WOW reports. The stress of working at a bank with management constantly down your back to go above and beyond for customers to increase/maintain customer satisfaction. Before I left they were doing almost daily observations on the teller line. Not enough career opportunities and not enough people in management willing to help. I think it's a bit silly that you have to work your way up through the branch just to get a job at corporate (with 2 university degrees).

review: "Employees are our greatest assets" is a false claim
pros: Wells Fargo is massive - which makes it easy to glide along doing very little actual work for many people.
cons: Middle management is bloated, and corporate policies are designed to minimize risk to the extent that almost nothing is done efficiently or well. Executive management are almost universally new to the company, and their goal is to transform the business - but they are doing so from an ivory tower and with ZERO loyalty or investment in the employees. They're building a new era of "cronyism" that is so obvious, I am left to speculate that the goal is to break the company up and sell it off in parts whilst pulling the rip cords on their golden parachutes.

review: Avoid - An executive suite that has lost their way
pros:
-The people you work with on a day-to-day basis are great.
-The work is interesting.
cons:
-The current focus of senior management is "cost cutting", which means lay offs (already happening), a reduction of resources/budgets, and limiting or changing benefits to make them cheaper for the company (and more expensive for employees)
-It is a big company so you are simply a number unless you are one of Charlie Scharf's friends or he recruited you over from JP Morgan. 
-Every position has a "bonus target" but that should be ignored. I have been with the bank for years and no one has ever received their targeted bonus, even in years where the bank performed well. There is also pressure on bonuses right now - more cost cutting - so even if you perform well you will not get even 95% of your bonus target.

pros: Some job security, health benefits, and 401k.
cons: Iâve been at this company for 4 years and have worked as a teller, banker, and now fraud specialist. Let me tell you, this company does not have their stuff together. If youâre a person who has a growth mindset then this place will disappoint you and ultimately hinder you. Management is horrible, you can express your concerns, problems, offer solutions and be enthusiastic about improvement and growing within the company. It really means nothing. Wells Fargo has no problem with demanding certain expectations of their employees when it comes to sales, production goals etc. However, they do not operate by the same standards. The workplace culture is more focused on micro management. (even though it appears no one really knows how to do their job) Lastly, they will implement changes randomly and add on more responsibility with little to no training or compensation. This place will truly have you working harder, making less, and confused about whether or not you actually know how to do your job.

pros: My colleagues at Wells Fargo were very professional and made my time there the highlight of my banking experience. Prior to the scandal the bankâs leadership outside of consumer banking had much more authority and the banks ability to be competitive was fun and winning meaningful relationships and positively impacting customers was commonplace. After the scandal became the central focus it was a completely different work place for all areas of the bank which 95% of the bank had nothing to do with the account scandal. The former leader of the consumer side of the business and her unquestioned support from the CEO of the bank at that time was the downfall for this organization.
cons: The bank lost its direction after the account scandal broke. No one employee including the CEO (he was in denial) really understood the changes that would be forthcoming once the effects of this fully took effect. The bank no longer was in control of its narrative nor was it capable of communicating to its employees what was going on with its regulatory enforcements that never stopped coming. Being an employee at Wells Fargo is not something I would recommend to anyone in the next few years unless you are looking for mission impossible and your work will never culminate into a feeling of satisfaction. My role was the tip of the spear in helping the bank bring in new customer relationships. As part of the banks effort to appease a multitude of its regulatory issues, the bank set up a number of safety towers or silos (operating separately of one another). This sounds like it was a good idea, but because the leaders of these various silos operated independently of each other and did not communicate it was a complete nightmare to get anything done productive and help create positive outcome. The time it took to board a new relationship is typically many months and not weeks as most banks board new clients. The culture of the bank has become one of fear and uncertainty. By in large there are fewer senior experienced bankers working as they are leaving for other opportunities. By in large, turnover is not occurring in higher salaried enployees despite the dysfunction because they wonât have someone pay them what they make at WF. The higher paid employees typically comprised of senior leadership are under tremendous pressure as their top performers are running over them getting out the door.

pros:
Salary
Benefits
PTO
401K
Stable, established company
Multiple jobs within the company, but very specialized which makes it difficult to get another job within WF
cons:
Work/Life Balance - All Work and No Life
I had lots of PTO, but there was too much work to do and I wasn't able to take time off.
Employees are not valued or recognized for great work.
Bottom-line profit and company reputation are what matter most.
I was on teams with people who did not take initiative, which made it impossible to effectively do my job.
As an East Coast employee, I was expected to stay online to accommodate West Coast team members. I was also expected to participate in evening conference calls to accommodate West Coast team members' busy schedules. The work/life balance of our teammates in India was never given much priority.
Teams operate in silos
Communication about changes to processes and procedures is poor and not timely
If you 'raise your hand' and question something, then you're frowned upon.

review: This job is not for everybody
pros: The starting salary is not bad especially starting off young. The PTO is great, we start off with 144 hours of PTO. That's about it.
cons: Wells Fargo call center jobs can be stressful and can cause a lot of anxiety depending on who you are. The customers can be very rude and the managers/ team leads (depending on who you get) abuse their role and can be unsupportive. From my experience, i was rushed through training. So, being on the floor has been difficult. my whole training class quit because no one felt equipped to do the job efficiently. All i have to say is, think twice before applying, if its not because you really like customer service or call center jobs and you're only applying for the hourly pay rate, you're going to find out very quickly that you will not like this job.

pros: Good benefits including PTO, 401K match, strong work life balance (at least in the area I worked) and most people were nice and giving of their time. Most of the company has been 100% WFH since COVID started.
cons:
Our new management team is pretty terrible. They are constantly talking about being more innovative and how things are going to change for the better only to take forever to approve things or figure out the new strategy. Lots of talk, little actual change. 
They are going through multi-year layoffs/cost cutting right now and laying off people every quarter which is so harmful for the culture as no one knows if they will be affected next. 
Very small pay increases every year(~2%) coupled with few opportunities to advance internally. 
Promotions were non existent in my area. 
Expect at times to be embarrassed by the companies actions, still dealing with churn from the sales practice scandal and other constant missteps

pros: Good benefits and good pay.
cons: It's highly dependent on who you work for. I worked in several departments during my tenure and there were massive "re-orgs" every few months. It's a big overblown company that can't figure itself out. They aren't work from home friendly, a big reason everyone jumps ship recently (when they aren't laying people off). This policy on this differs manager to manager and isn't global. Work life balance can be great with one manager and horrible with another. I was told verbatim from the top-down that promotions are only going to be given to those who "put in extra work on nights and weekends.". Maybe you'll get lucky and have a manager that doesn't believe in that, maybe you'll end up in a bad group. HR is a big mess - I've dealt with really nice people who want to help you and others who were some of the most rude and unprofessional people I've had the displeasure of speaking with. I'd highly recommend that you do a LOT of Q&A during your interview with the hiring manager to make sure it's where you want to be.

pros: Strong financially given its top rank in Commercial Banking. Good culture for diversity. Acceptable salary and benefit levels. Plenty of opportunity for expense cuts to increase operating ratio, plus retail brick and mortar downsizing.
cons: Slow, antiquated internal systems. Customer interface systems given priority. Reputation slowly recovering from deposit/auto insurance/home mortgage scandals. Focusing on upscale Commercial clients at the expense of smaller Business Banking clients (who become wholesale clients).

review: Middle of the road , typical big corporation
pros: The salary was average for the position at the company but the benefits were probably the best part of the job. Tuition reimbursement, affordable health insurance, HSA dollars, lots of PTO, paid volunteer days.
cons: The work itself was unfulfilling, the work environment was your typical stuffy cubicle with management hovering over you, the yearly pay increases were a joke (less than 1%), work from home (pre pandemic) was NOT an option even if there was a blizzard, and management would jerk you around promising promotions and raises then not delivering.

review: Benefits keep declining while workload increases
pros: Being such a large company, there's opportunity for growth and personal/professional development. There's a lot to learn, and if you don't like what you're doing, you can try something else in another area. Pay is competitive, for the most part.
cons: There used to be so many great benefits/perks of working at WF. Those benefits made up for working very long hours, having to work unexpectedly during PTO, skipping a lunch break to eat on mute during back-to-back meetings, etc. When you have to work 8am-7pm regularly as a salaried employee, being able to do so at home makes it sting a lot less. Now that they are taking away the ability to work from home most days, I can't imagine how I will get all of the work done and commute home in time to start dinner, exercise, take care of kids, etc. just to wake up, sit in traffic, and do it all over again. I'm going to have to start saying no to the new assignments that come to me at 5pm and are due at 8am. Taking away the ability for high performing/producing employees to spend their long workdays at home is really disappointing. Especially when we've been doing it for over a decade, and other companies are offering it even more now. Other benefits have also been taken away recently - no raises last year for certain level of employees, no 401K match until Dec 31, cell phones taken away, laptops are next. I want to remain a loyal employee but it is getting more difficult every year.

pros: I have met the best people working for Wells Fargo.

Usually the company will promote or hire individuals that are presentable enough but are not really educated. They do this so that the pay can remain low with quality service.

pros: Pays better than most of their competitors in the same market
cons:
Silos, politics, no 360 feedback system, employee satisfaction surveys are rare and when performed they are not anonymous, no skip level meetings, strategic planning includes "how do we pin this on someone else", regular reminders to be suspicious of peer teams that might try to "pin something on us", no accountability, employee performance calibration is always opinion based not goal based. Cronyism from the top down. 

TLDR; If you take the ignorance and indifference that led to the account opening scandal and add the dumbest people from JPMC you'd just be scratching the surface of this train wreck.

review: The company is burning to the ground and thatâs why everyone is leaving it.
pros: The pay is competitive for entry level work.  There are benefits and 401k and a generous amount of PTO.
cons: All of Wells Fargo is understaffed and is requiring their employees to run their branches with barely any staff.  Employees are drained and overworked while dealing with equally overworked customers who more often than not cannot be helped. Wells Fargo has butchered their line of products leaving nothing for bankers to offer in branch and continue to downsize staff and products with no explanation. The company is going under and doing nothing to make it easier for their suffering staff.

The job security is also very weak here. They recently decided to downsize and either move employees to other branches or simply fire them. It makes the customer service awful with longer wait times for customers and also theyâve made some decisions that hurt the customers financially all to protect their own profits. Be prepared to constantly file customers complaints because you will get them all day long. Theyâve also claimed to get rid of sales goals but the pressure is still there and threaten to fire you if you donât sell enough. This bank doesnât care about its employee or customers.

cons: The particular department doesn't seem to know what its doing. I will say that I've heard from other employees that it is slowly an issue with this department, but it is not run well. You feel like you have your hands tied behind your back and you can't really help the customers that call in. You get cussed out every day and no time to really decompress. Every second of your day is measured, including bathroom breaks and you're not able to walked away or hang up on disruptive customers. You are expected to take everything coming your way and it takes a mental toll. What makes it worse is that despite knowing the mental struggle that this can have on people, management treats it as it helps weed out the weak that shouldn't be in the company.

pros: Good PTO Package; Large Company; Decent Pay
cons: There is a lot of change going on at Wells Fargo and it isn't headed in the right direction. There is so much red tape that it is challenging to get anything done efficiently, they are having significant layoffs, not prioritizing young talent, and the CEO's only concern seems to be deeply cutting costs within the organization rather than taking the time to figure out how to increase revenue. It used to be an organization that seemed to respect tenure and truly care for its employees but as far as I can tell, those days are over. If you want to work for a bank that is trying to become like JPM but pays less, then it might be a good choice.

pros: There was great PTO and benefits. You get a decent bonus if your have a good performance month.
cons: The work itself was energetically draining. Youâre slouched over a computer dealing with difficult people for 7 hours on the phone taking one call right after the other. Corporate pressures management to be up your butt if you make one wrong move. They donât let you forget your every move is being watched. Itâs not for everyone. The pay is decent while youâre training because itâs a huge learning curve and youâre bound to make a lot of mistakes at the beginning, but after a few months of getting it down, I think pay should have a big increase. Not only do customer give you a hard time, people internally can be horrible and toxic to you as well. Given the nature of the work and the energy required, I think the pay should be way better after training.

pros: The pay and benefits were great and we were allowed a not at all unreasonable amount of PTO, holidays, etc. There was a pay differential if you chose to work later hours as well, and extra pay if you worked holidays. 401k was good and I enjoyed the free savings account that I opened after becoming employed with them. Working in person, the campus on which training took place was really cool and had all kinds of things that made being at work convenient. I could have easily lived in that building if such a thing were allowed. I hope other locations are anything like it.
cons:
Training was simultaneously very thorough and very sink-or-swim at the same time. I felt mostly prepared going into the role but once I was on the floor taking calls I realized quickly how much had been left out. There were a great deal of important job functions that weren't covered in training that I and the others who trained with me had to ask coworkers about. 

Time on the phones and time in general was very micromanaged down to the minute. If you spent too long on a call or too long in wrap it was only a matter of time until someone was on the case about it no matter how reasonable it was or how detailed the notes were. This isn't necessarily true of the company as a whole but in my role with my boss I felt as though my failures were recognized disproportionately to my successes.

At the time that I was working with Wells Fargo the company was in the news a lot for any number of scandals. We were always being emailed about them and briefed on how to respond if certain things came up in conversation, or how to redirect them to a team geared to speak with the media and things like that. It was frustrating having to keep on top of it all, especially when most of it had nothing to do with my role whatsoever.

Lastly, collections for home mortgage was just a distressing job. That isn't Wells Fargo's fault but it's true of the role even so. It was difficult to hear people talk about the massive obstacles in their life getting in the way of them paying their home loan and hearing their distress in being told they're at risk of losing their home if they don't pay, and there's only so much we as employees can do about that. Being unable to help people beyond a certain extent when their only wrongdoing is not having money to live on felt terrible and acknowledging that on the floor felt like an admission of weakness. I felt like "the bad guy" a lot. It wasn't the worst job but I'm glad I don't work there anymore.

cons: The compensation plan disincentivizes bankers from achieving their full potential. Wells Fargo seems to starve bankers rather than reward them for their work. Equivalent positions like the Premier Banker II makes more money with the base salary and bonuses. I was hired for the position with a $50,000 per year pay when PB II's are making $55,000- $60,000.

review: Toxic workplace for AI & Design Teams
pros: At first, it was nice to be one of the early recruits in the AI team
cons:
- Constant management turn-over, highly-skilled executives end up leaving because senior management insists on working old-fashion Wells Fargo way of doing things instead of being open-minded and considering new ways of working
- Managers hire "diverse" people to increase diversity and inclusion, but people they end up hiring come with no experience, straight out of college, and the rest of the team is tasked with onboarding new employees
- Forget about any promotion or career growth unless you have "connections" in the senior management, or you've proven yourself and got the OK of senior management
- there are some really misogynistic project managers who openly violate workplace ethics, intimidation, and harassment, and managers turn a blind eye to issues raised
- Ethics line has a lot of complaints coming from AI organizations, but they don't follow-up
- AI Trainings are handled absurdly and anyone who raises red flags get retaliation or asked to drop the case and accept unethical data training management
- Product designs are mediocrely accepted into production in order to meet "product deadlines"

pros: Wells Fargo really works with their people and trains from the ground up
cons:
Corporate takes WAY to long to hire anyone. There is no help, customers are angry about the long wait times and they take it out on the staff who are trying their absolute best. 

You only get a 30 minute break, even if you work 8 hours. Normally you get two 15 minute breaks and a 30, but since there is no one to cover - you don't get to take a break from nasty, rude, and condescending customers.

You are expected to keep smiling and say things perfectly and with the perfect tone, or you will get disciplined. Staff is absolutely pushed to their breaking point with no understanding from managers or breaks to cool off from tough interactions.

If you get it wrong - don't be surprised that you are blamed for the entire interaction (even if the customer started off in a foul mood) and then shamed for not being perfect 100% of the time. I understand being good to the customer, but with no breaks, long lines out the door, rude and nasty customers, and managers who refuse to see their staff at their boiling point - yeah you are not going to have a perfect customer interaction every single time.

review: They need to clean up their act big time.
pros: Decent benefits. But not worth it.
cons: I had left my position within 2 months of joining. They care about burn down charts and statistics, and not the quality of the work being done. Micromanagement rules there. Managers are abusive and this is non productive for getting anything done. They offer destructive criticism.  The managers are people that have been at wells since the beginning of time so their is no touching them, but at the end of the day, Wells will suffer for not cleaning up their rotting upper management. I felt I was working more towards preserving my narcissist manager's ego rather than working for Wells Fargo itself. Instead of looking into the system and learning the code, I felt I was studying for my one on one meetings with the tyrant. Maybe it was my team, but I could see they really need to clean up the act. Managers need not use constant intimidation tactics. Not only do they do that, managers also keep a few brown nosing suck ups to keep tabs on others for them. People are so insecure about their jobs that they do not help anyone out, and collaboration is dead in the water.

review: Good idea for entry, but not for the long term, unless you "know" someone.
pros:
- Ability to contribute to HSA
- 6% 401K match 
- School reimbursement, but work's schedule, & company's interest comes before yours. "It's a business, after all", been told.
- Great direct management team.
- Friendly co-workers.
- Dress code tends to be relaxed, as long as it's appropriated, and professional.
- May be a good stepping stone to get into the finance world.
cons:
- Very micro-managing.
- Rules & regulations are made & given by bunch of CEOs, etc., who have no idea how the real branches work. 
- Long process(es) to get something done.
- Sale practices are being replaced by contanst reviews of the CNAs, BNAs, & # of referrals from the management. 
- Raises are being replaced by customers' quarterly average of reviews, & surveys.
- Extremely under-staffed.
- A person's education, knowledge, years of service, level of customer service, or # of licenses don't mean a squat, but the ability of "kissing the right places", definitely do wonders.
- The memory of the scandals are tattooed in the public's minds. Customers still bring them up from time to time, & employees are still being hammered for something they didn't do.
- Just like with all big companies, anyone is replaceable.
- Extremely difficult to move up.
- Pay is low, compare to the company's competitors. Typical 2% annual raise, if there's any.

review: Wells Fargo is an excellent "Training Ground" for new and experienced bankers
pros: Happiness and the feeling of "family" and a good "work-life balance" is dependent upon the department for which you work (i.e. Business Banking, Regional Commercial Banking, the Retail "branch" Bank, Real Estate, Residential Mortgage or Mortgage, Private Bank, Wealth Advisor and/or the Trust department, etc.
cons: Just as it is with other large corporate entities, you will want to think carefully before you speak and give your opinions. Perhaps, you can take some personality assessments in order to determine your own personality and work traits, along with those of your supervisor. And, your days can go long as you move up the ladder, so time management becomes critical to be able to carry over work to the next day and go home on time or close to "on time".

review: Agile and forced co-location won't fix this place
pros:
Good WLB as WFH
Good starting pay
Bonuses have been ok
Some good managers
Many co workers are extremely helpful
Learning at least a dozen new technologies annually
cons:
Microscopic raises, don't keep up with COL
No room for advancement.
Most managers too busy shining a light on their careers to help their employees.
Too many self-interested, cut throat peers.
Little ability to apply newly learned technology, as it's often dumped for the next new shiny toy.
Agile cannot fix what's wrong here. Some maybe, but not all
Pigeonholing all of IT into engineering roles, and eliminating all roles without "engineer" in the title does not mean IT will produce more, or produce efficiently
Too many JPMC hires in upper management
Too many secret consulting firm lead projects pretending to know how to fix this place.
Not enough to senior leadership walking the talk.
Not enough senior leadership ensuring that other senior leaders are held accountable for bad behavior.

pros: There are some great leaders, mentors, and team members. I've heard horror stories, but I've been fortunate to avoid the landmines of toxic leadership and apathetic peers. Senior leadership has flipped over quite a bit so it's hard to judge, but the current CEO seems genuine. Whether the high turnover was a series of choices or suggestions is anyone's guess, but the end result is a small consolation to people that lost their jobs in the past due to a leadership team that encouraged bad behavior. The future looks brighter than the past.
cons: Much lower pay than competitors. A peer was fired for performance after 15 years with Wells Fargo. He (or She) was hired by a competitor for nearly double the pay and went on to be a top performer at that company. My former peer heard about the job opening from several high performers that left Wells Fargo to accept better pay for the same role. It's frustrating to see poor performers retained year after year when top performers walk out the door.

review: Great place to work if you focus on you!
pros:
Great technology stack, you will learn however much effort you put in.

If you shine and perform it will be noted and will help further your career

Great benefits 

Great people
cons:
Like all big companies, there are office politics. But if you focus on yourself, do your work, and perform well consistently, you will do great.

Required to work from the office. The work from home option is there but you can only use it on occasions. No work from remote permanent option.

Once you get noticed and are given more work and responsibilities your work-life balance gets seriously scewed. Anywhere up to 40 - 55 hours per week is normal at that point. Weekend work is there not always but often times.

review: Recovering Company, but had the best job and team ever
pros: I was lucky enough to work which such a great team. We all kept it real and made sure our work life was enjoyable. I learned so much of the financial world. Was there for 2.5 years. Easy to learn, good if you are going to school for business. You do not need a degree to work at a branch in literally every job they have, you can even work your way up but the jobs that require a degree is where its at.
cons:
getting bad things thrown at you cuz of what cooperate has done when you have done nothing. Before the pandemic hit, the bank was experiencing some company issues that made it hard to grow. Once COVID hit, the latter was completely cut off. I left the company because it started to become %100 impossible to grow.
They dont pay the best but not the worst compared to other banks/credit unions

review: Decent company culture, but too many changes in Executive management

- Layoffs are common...never feel completely at ease

review: Lots of changes, not all good.
pros: Lots of opportunities if you know the right people.
cons: Once upon a time everyone was a team member, we've since become regular old employees. The real issue is that they've spent a lot of time bringing in Sr. Execs from outside. But all the mgmt that created a lot of the problems are still in place and nothing is going to change. Everything comes from the top down whether right or not. Any claim to want open communications, is simply not true.

cons: Still need to do some house cleaning at the top of the house.

pros: Hard to give anything good currently.
cons:
Wells is pulling their employees back into the office and not letting more people work from home even though it would save them millions every year. Even after this pandemic and we've proved that most businesses can operate like normal in a more widely WFH model! It's ridiculous. Many jobs are being limited to high cost areas, and teams are still all over the country so you're still just video calling eachother even in the office.

Their policies need to change to the current decade and ease up, allowing for more WFH.

review: Gone down since new CEO came in
pros: Great benefits, a lot of time away from work options, tremendous DE&I efforts, great investment in many major city communities (US and international).
cons: Available US work locations, poor tone from the top, "do more with less" attitude from management, inability to move around in career due to new location strategy of only about 15 cities in US eligible to work in. Constant fear of being laid off due to not living in one of the location strategy cities or always worked from home (which this option will be going away for many folks). There is a reason our CEO has the nickname "Chainsaw Charlie". He is at least living up to that. Technology is seriously lagging even though there are "grand plans" for all sorts of enhancements. Focus is more on "centralizing" and "streamlining" versus what is best for an employee, a team, group or the firm.

You can be the most talented and hard working and most productive individual, but somebody else in your team could be doing nothing productive all day but could be getting a much higher salary than you. No value for MBA. If you are old or a woman, you will be hired to a manager position much easily. No value for productive work. If you can speak good English or say few words on the call, you can keep your position without knowing anything. All you have to say is "we should engage person 1, person 2 to do this thing blah blah..."

If you are technical, do not even think of joining this company. Your talents wont be appreciated..

Maybe WF is a fabulous place to work if you are a teller or so junior that you don't know any better. It was the worst place I have ever worked and I have had some terrible jobs. My colleagues were great as were many of my internal clients (though many of them, mainly Charlie Scharf buddies) were pretty awful. The bureaucracy and awful technology made getting your work done nearly impossible, meanwhile the volume and pace were out of control. And your days are packed with useless meetings. Attrition rates were high and when people left, everyone was enviousm

review: Much improved bank but still has opportunities
pros: Great culture, really about customers first and courtesy, relaxed sales environment as its more about relationship building. Appointment based for bankers allows more time to prepare and plan to make appointments effective.
cons: Inconsistencies between the branch and phone bank leads to customer dissatisfaction. Current downsizing resulted stressful environment. Inconsistent branch operations leads to customer dissatisfaction. Little ability to submit employee feedback to the upper management.

review: Good company at first, empty promises start to show
pros:
Retirement plan is good but they just transferred it over to Empower
You get great employee benefits and amazing PTO time
You get a discounted rate if you need to take a loan out from your retirement
Long maternity leave
cons: If you plan on moving up there are many empty promises even if you put in the work. We were given a chance to work remote temporarily for 4 months and they had announced it would be for Business PPP loans. I agreed to transfer roles from Personal Banker so I would have more exposure in that thinking it would be a temporary position that would last a few months. We go through training and it turns out they transferred us to a regular call center for customer service having nothing to do with PPP loans. It was a way for Wells Fargo to remove personal bankers and make room for more licensed bankers. Prior to my decision to work remote I was waiting to start my licensed banker training and the district manager had announced they removed sponsoring the license. Now I am stuck working in the call center within Wells Fargo and have all this PTO time that is impossible to schedule within a call center and there are no holiday hours because the call center is available 24/7. I wasnât the only Personal Banker that this happened to and several others were tricked into thinking it would be a temporary position to enhance our skills in Business. It was described as such by our District manager- and the licensed bankers who applied were the only people who were able to return from the âtemporary positionâ they were all called back in to their branches. When bankers started speaking up and we all communicated in training that this wasnât what we signed up for they âescalatedâ it to HR and weâve heard nothing since. The unfortunate part of this all is that call center locations are located in more rural areas and there is no call center in the state I am in. So whatâs going to happen to us that are not physically located near these call centers when everything opens up? Remote work is not going to be forever especially as a call center representative. I believe by then they will weed us out instead of furloughing us or firing us because the company wasnât doing well during COVID this is the tactic they used to displace us slowly since they didnât want any bad media for what they are doing to us. I wish they had just let us go before because we would have received unemployment benefits at the time since we didnât receive any bonus for working during covid as essential workers. They will end up giving us an ultimatum as things begin to reopen- either quit or move to the state where the call center location is open to resume work. Weâll see how this scheme of theirs goes!

review: Ok place to work depending on what you do
pros: Low level management is usually as supportive as they are allowed to be. Great people working at WF overall. People are normally very willing to help you. Has some good benefits like 4 months paid parental leave. Once you get in you can move around somewhat easily. work/life balance is good unless you are an analyst of some sort.
cons: Poor company/staff moral. Lots of layoffs and on the banking side you are forced to reapply for the job you currently have. No surprise when the keep only the people they can pay less. If you are in a field that isn't banking specific then the upper level management runs the show but doesn't know how things operate at the lower levels. In the WF tech world its normal to see managers overseeing an engineering group who have no engineering experience. Mid level/upper level management in tech fields are normally MBA's with a finance background who know little about the systems they support. Most of the systems and processes make no sense. Every 2-3 years everything changes depending on who's in charge and before the dust settles it changes again... usually to the way it was prior. You can bet that management will always go for the cheaper option vs the better option. Scandal after scandal after government mandate was caused by poor sr. management. Many of those managers are still around but were moved to different areas of the bank.

pros: There benefits are good, what you'd expect. The pay is livable, after a couple years showing you're reliable. This company has resources available to support employees, and used to be known for that, but nowadays seems driven to do so mostly by backlogs.
cons:
Training is a slapdash, and managers are revolving doors often not fully knowing how to do what their team does. Being competent earns you harder work, higher volumes, and pressure to be a resource for (train) your coworkers.
As a grunt, you need to let your manager know how they can help you. Too bad managers are stuck in daily meetings with upper management. So, they're hard pressed for time other than when they do get around to meet with you for your monthly meeting, and any other meetings where they reward your competency by asking you to help unclog a backlog, or ask you to give ideas on how you can prevent mistakes from occurring again.
Everyone's overloaded, but the pressure on the grunts where jobs actually land is immense. Then jobs are reassigned to competent saps who show up to work every day. To top it off, the branches pushing the credits are belligerent and any feigned positive communication they give belies the overall abusive culture.

pros: Pay is ok, 8 hours per day, 1 hour lunch break, reliable income. Decent benefits. Not a bad "filler" job while you look for something better. Dont let the title fool you, it's a collections job.
cons:
HIGH TURNOVER. You're paid to be an emotional punching bag for customers. Constantly calling customers all day, poor training, there is a rush to get people on the floor to answer calls even if they don't know what they're doing. Assisstance from leaders can be really slow, exaserbating the negative situation.

A lot of the people who were in my training class have quit. They stress customer service and customer satisfaction / loyalty, but the business actively creates issues to produce upset customers (call customers on due dates, being forced to ask the same repetitive questions). 

Some people caught and spread COVID while there.

Overall, a typical fast-paced collections job in a fancy / nice disguise.

review: Moving in the wrong direction for employees
pros:
Great Coworkers
Competitive Products and Services
Opportunities
Benefits
cons:
Bank sanctions have grossly impacted the work environment for all employees not just those in the retail business. There are now more risk officers than front line, customer facing employees. 
Wells Fargo used to be more balanced with regards to stakeholder concerns. Today, employees are unfortunately the clear bottom of that list.
Recently, Wells has steadily stripped benefits such as changing 401K match from quarterly to annual, reduced performance incentive payouts, etc.
Cost cutting measures are heavy handed and impacting employees ability to perform the job

review: Company is still working through transition

pros: Flexible hours, work from home, Microsoft, Java, Database, or UI developers have state of the art tools and related technologies available to them.
cons: Application development/maintenance is heavily influenced by a chaotic production environment. You will spend your day in meetings, supporting production defects/outages, reacting to planned/unplanned events like tons of security patching/upgrades. IT policy changes from day-to-day with poor communication. Application customers are a nightmare -- you ending up telling them what their application does, they don't know (due to an equally chaotic corporate environment). Good luck getting quality code written, unless you do that on your own time. Did I mention chaotic?

pros: Decent pay, opportunity to work from hime.
cons:
Very high turnover. Answer to most issues is "It's a production environment" means you're rushed to get through calls, if you need a bathroom break you're penalized. They really emphasize customer service during training but really downplay the upset customers.

It's a collections position, if customers are upset with Wells Fargo (which most in collections are) you get marked down for that. Banking error or other company created issues make a customer upset? You get penalized for that.

pros: Vacation time starting is 10 days with 2 personal holidays. After being ther 3 or more years you get an additional 5 days. You also get all federal holidays including Columbus day. Health insurance is great and if you are under 40k the company contributes to your HSA if that is the plan you chose. You also have the opportunity of doing health tests and such to potentially get an additional $800 for you and an additional $800 for your spouse in your HSA. Company does want to change and they stress doing what is best for the customer, which I feel like in this location we do. We are told not to pressure the customer into anything and conversations really are tailored to what the customer needs.
cons: Work-life balance is not the best. It's hard to get to doctor appointments because it seems we are always short handed and I felt pressured to stay at work rather than go to my appointments. You are expect to have sales but don't call it sales or "pressure" you to have sales. But in reality they do pressure with CNA completion goals and for tellers conversation starters. But it's not bad at all.

The management did not advocate for its workers. When issues arose about a specific manager over the course of months, the solution was to move them to another team instead of addressing the problems. That is how Wells is. pros: Itâs hard to beat the benefits of working for a corporation like Wells. They offer everything from tuition assistance to maternity/paternity leave, 401k matching and profit sharing to employee counseling. Every holiday is off and paid, PTO, and a corporate structure to provide a consistent experience and job where ever you work.
cons: Being part of a corporation also means you are dispensable. If you find employment elsewhere, they donât fight to keep you. Itâs hard at times not to feel like a number, even if you do all you can to keep things running well.

review: Nothing has changed, itâs still the old Wells Fargo.
pros: The work/life balance is satisfactory
cons: Everything else about the company. Instead of management pressuring employees to meet aggressive sales goals theyâve simply shifted the focus to activities they deem will produce the same results. The harassment from management is still as unhealthy today as it was when the company was fined billions of dollars for deceptive sales practices. They tout candor and transparency but itâs all a ruse; management says one thing to satisfy the regulators and implements daily practices at the branch level that are completely contradictory. Be careful.

pros:
- Salary! I make six figures and get a bonus. Itâs incredible. 
- Supportive bosses
- Wonderful benefits, especially medical and vacation. Max out of pocket deductible for 2021 is $3500 for me. I think they start you with three weeks of vacation, then give you four when you hit three years. You also get two personal days, two days to volunteer, and a bunch of federal holidays.
- Wonderful advancement opportunities. You can also see the pay scale if itâs an internal job posting.
- Awesome work/life balance. I can start my day at 9 and shut off my computer around 6. Could depend on my job, but there has rarely been an instance where I had to work super late.

I have to also give them kudos for putting a lot of emphasis on diversity and inclusion lately.
cons:
Since itâs a huge corporation, there are lots of rules/parameters/processes you must work within. The slow pace can get a bit maddening sometimes.

The interview process can be quite tough as well.

Needs more women/POC at the top.

review: Decent place to work but not worth it if you donât want to make your way up
pros: The employees are typically very nice and the workplace is a friendly atmosphere. Paid holidays and PTO is a nice benefit. Wells Fargoâs goal is to have each employee move up so itâs easier to do so but there is a needed time period between each position and the pay doesnât go up significantly.
cons: The pay isnât good for the work involved. Bank teller is the most entry level position at Wellsfargo and treated very undervalued by bankers and management while itâs usually the most busy and detail specific job. It is also the most dangerous. I worked at two branches, one small and one large at Wells Fargo and I would recommend the small branch 100%. At larger branches, it is consistently busy all day with not many chances to fix your station, count your cash, do any side tasks, let alone breathe. There is more tellers at these larger branches but at both branches, they are consistently short staffed and overworked.

review: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times
pros: The job has benefits including health, dental, and vision insurance, and a 401(k) matching up to 6%. Stock options are also available. Unlimited overtime available, if you want. The insurance is paid through your paycheck with your choice of coverage. Pay is significantly higher than surrounding businesses in the area for an entry level position.
cons: The insurance you can get doesn't cover much outside of the basics unless you go over your deductible. Mandatory overtime issued with little regard to life outside company. Policies and processes change weekly/monthly when you just got used to the most recent change. The company and ADCC department continually implement negative policies affecting workers. The programs used by the department are severely outdated with an "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" mentality. System issues are a rampant, daily problem. Feedback and suggestions given to management are largely ignored. Mental health is not taken seriously, with only a helpline number given as a Band-aid if you wish to speak with Wells Fargo approved counselors. Promotions include significantly more work with little compensation to match it.
