pros:
Great benefits. Insurance options are plenty and add on options such as life insurance and legal services are very reasonably priced. Company matches up to 6% on your 401k and they provide plenty of vacation hours to use.
Work life can vary by branch and management but employees are generally fun and engaging.
cons:
For the amount of work and responsibility that lies on you, pay is underwhelming. Expectations are unrealistic. Though there arenât any sales goals, they focus heavy on âactivitiesâ which are supposed to help generate sales. 
Policies seem to change frequently with little or no notice to employees and training isnât provided on many services the bank offers.
Work life varies by branch and management. If your lucky youâll have a branch manager that is actually resourceful and skilled enough to help you develop.

review: I would generally not recommend this position to new accounting graduates
pros: Good Starting Salary, Vacation, Medium Workload, and Retirement Benefits
cons:
I spent ten months with Wells Fargo. I spent six months doing work that was completely unrelated to my auditing job with the RCC team. I understood that this was due to COVID-19 and dealt with it. When I finally made it to my audit team I received very little guidance on what my job was, how to do it, and when tasks were due. Things were continuing to get worse as time went on and I felt that these factors were making doing the audit with a reasonable standard of competency impossible. I was told that other audit associates had different experiences on their teams but this was also told to me by the recruiter during what was effectively an exit interview. Training is very inconsistent in quality and depends largely on which audit team you are assigned.

The work itself is fairly easy but it requires accessing multiple systems of record and these are not intuitive systems that you'll be able to find by guesswork. You'll need training on how to do all of this as well and that was largely the problem I ran into with my team. I felt like my degree in accounting and previous work experience in accounting were largely useless here. Ultimately I left because I felt that my lack of knowledge was negatively affecting my performance on the job and also my teams performance as they relied on my to do audit work and other work.

review: Horrible experience! Not really an HR role
pros:
Pay
Benefits
Time off
Many opportunities to move around
cons:
Constantly changing procedures
High case load
Low recognition
No consistency 
Low team morale
Nobody willing to help
This is not an HR role anymore. 

If you value having a high paying job, this is it! Other than that, nothing special about the role. They took a simple job and over complicated it and never asked us for our opinions. 

New processes almost weekly because âthe regulatorsâ say so, but no explanations given. 

You will be handling mostly customer related cases where the customer is mad at every little thing. 

This role is lucky to have any type of âHRâ work to it. 

Management does not seem to care about the numerous redundant processes in place. 

Good luck trying to get anything more than meeting expectations, even though, they assign 3 new cases each week on top of your already growing case load. 

EXTREMELY micro-managed by managers who have been there too long.

A lot of change (wasn't bad change) for the company but when the change happened there was not enough training on the new policy or procedure. Systems are outdated and changing constantly with no advance notice. Since COVID-19 they have been in a hiring freeze and the DM does not know how to properly staff branches. 80% of the branches are short staff and they have not started the hiring process.

review: Finding good plans here like finding a desert in the middle of the ocean
pros: It is a job and pays bills
cons:
The English language fails to truly describe how awful of a company this truly is. "Do as we say; don't do as we do" should be the moto.
Example Set 1: Having your work badge sent to the wrong city, having inoperable devices dropped on your desk, and not having the tech staff show up to be sure your systems are working until after you have done their job for them in the first week.
Example set 2: Having systems so slow they compete with dialup speeds, and you are doing jobs that require processing of tens of thousands of records. This is only one example of how the company will routinely set you up without what you need. It would be about the equivalent of a mechanic being asked to fix a car with their bare hands and hardly any tools.
Example Set 3: Constant hypocracy. Transparency, candidness, honesty are talked about frequently as company values. On the flip side, there is a compliance department that requires you to disclose all of your investment activity without even telling you what they are doing with it, or informing you about who has access. If you bother to express your dissatisfaction in a candid manner, you are reprimanded because nobody is to dare challenge that department. 
I could go on and on. You will find constantly you are told to follow one process, and then before even giving you enough time to switch, the company will change processes not giving you the chance to adjust, or even get the right footing. There are processes in place that might even be illegal (like the surveillance of your investments). You will not find more sloppy communication than what you will see here. If you are a low-level hire, and can't find a job somewhere else, you might love it here. It is definitely a place for people with incredibly low standards.

pros:
Coworkers. My colleagues were hands down my favorite part of working at WF. They were smart and didn't take themselves too seriously, especially compared to other competing groups.

Opportunities - Joining WF gives flexibility to change departments. It's not uncommon for a credit analyst to move into interest rate sales, for example. By being part of such a large organization, you have access to a large network of opportunities in different departments and geographies.
cons: In the aftermath of WF's account scandal, management was spending significant time and energy trying to prevent similar mistakes. As a company, we were spending so much time trying to either clean up past mistakes or avoid future ones, that it was hard to unite around a future vision. Personally, I would have preferred to work at a company with a positive vision - something we were trying to accomplish - rather than just trying to defend revenue.

review: Small work group makes everyone close.
pros: The times I enjoyed my time at wellsfargo was how close we all were with each other in the branch. They made sure the work atmosphere was fun, they would celebrate team members birthdays. I really enjoyed once a month your boss would sit down with you and talk about your progress, what you're doing good and what you can work on. You would make obtainable goals and they would help you achieve each goal.
cons: It's quite unfortunate but I had to fight to get my breaks, didn't get them until I contacted the district manager. I was also hired as a 20 hour teller but they were working me 40+ hours per week with only Sunday off. It was exhausting especially because I didn't get my breaks. There was a lot of work place drama and no one would hold the people spreading drama accountable. I had one team member bully me and be extremely rude to me in front of customers. She would only get talked to but nothing would change. Some team members would talk ill about other members, they wouldn't celebrate someone birthday because he didn't participate in anyone's birthday (bring some kind of food or buy something for someone) They also completely forgot about mine until I said something and the branch manager just threw me a happy birthday card while with a customer. It makes you feel horrible when everyone gets a birthday party with balloons, streamers, flowers and big signs. I didn't get any of that. It was a very toxic environment to work in and I'm glad I'm out of it. However the company was great to work for but the branch I worked at was horrendous and toxic.

review: Director Technology  â Powerful Strategist | Business Transformation | Risk Management | Operational Excellence
pros:
An accomplished and business savvy professional with robust experience acquired over the years in delivering optimal results & business value in high-growth environments and establishing key relationships with business segments globally. An insightful information Technology Director with more than 15 years of experience specializing in strategic business leadership, technology expertise, and generating revenue growth. Track record of success increasing profits while handling complex matters with multiple initiatives in rapidly evolving technology sectors. Thrive in navigating ever-changing business needs and emerging technologies, improving operational processes, systems, and security, and continuously drives cost savings and fiscal efficiency. Devise a new strategy based on increased utilization, development of lower-cost technologies, updated certification methodologies, accelerated commercialization schedule, and improved allocations. Known for rapidly identifying issues by using root causes analysis and responding with plans and execution that resolve problems and often improve on previous operations. Continually assessing for opportunities to drive culture adoption and integration, optimize operations and processes, and drive customer success and client engagement. Ensure organizational efficiency, agility, and highest levels of operational capability to meet business demands and deliver growth objectives. Demonstrate a record of driving continuous improvements within and across teams. Exceptional communication, presentation & interpersonal skills with proficiency at grasping new concepts quickly and utilizing the same in a productive manner. 
~Successfully led all aspects of long-term technology strategy and tactical execution to support nearly 29K users. Managed up to $5M annual budget and up to $20M project budgets ~
~ Ensured the efficiency, effectiveness, and viability of 385 critical applications, 890 end-user created applications, 90 desktop applications, and 243 critical websites ~
~ Led design of $12M telecommunication infrastructure ~
~ Developed, directed, designed, and implemented a comprehensive data and video WAN for 46 school districts and 32 public libraries ~

review: They treat their employees better than they treat the majority of their customers.
pros: 6% 401(k) match, tuition reimbursement, random rewards (i.e., received RSR's in the amount of 50 shares for full-time, equating to about $3000 and vested within 2 year;, COVID hazard pay granted an additional $200 per week if needed in office, even if only for a day; $600 gratitude bonus for swift transition to working at home), generous employer HSA contributions + monetary incentives, for HSA, to improve lifestyle, free banking, reduced interest rates, reduced foreign currency exchange rates, no sales goals (within branches and phone banking, they only ask that you push recommendations to use their mobile app and self-service tools) but the list goes on. They, truly, seem like they want you to stay with their company throughout your career.
cons: Due to the prior reputation damage from class-actions and bad media, if/when the company receives additional bad media coverage, customers tend to doubt your credibility and they all try to seek out the 'next big suit'. Also due to this, your work is getting randomly audited and a higher rate than you would see at another financial institution, plus they use such a fine tooth comb. The CEO changed 3 times... within 3 years of working there. They never know how to handle themselves in front of congress, lol. nice job sloan. This specific role in housed in a cubical farm, it is in a beautiful building and the office is gorgeous, but teamwork and verbal communications are nearly impossible due to the layout and the fact that everyone is listening to music or podcasts. You have a production quota in order to evade disciplinary action and poor assessment scores, leading to a minimal raise of >$.15, if anything, and an inability to apply to a new role within the company.

pros: The benefits are not the worst. PTO isn't bad. Life insurance, AD&D, etc.
cons:
The company has gone through huge changes. The sales quota fiasco was a nightmare to live through, and the culture has remained. It's all about numbers. Micromanagement is present everywhere you look. Constant 1-on-1 meetings with your manager, constant evaluations. A very toxic work environment. 

Ultimately a lot of your experience at WF will depend on your Branch Manager. Branch Managers are promoted based on meeting sales goals, not their skill at managing teams. This leads to a whole team of bullying managers. People at my branch dreaded coming to work each day and celebrated when the Branch Manager was gone.

A lot has been done to repair the company's image. But employee morale is at an all-time-low with layoffs, quotas (yes, they still exist), and increasing micromagement. Employees are unhappy, customers are still being pressured, and the company is not doing well financially. It is, without a doubt, a sinking ship.

review: Great company if you are in the right department
pros:
Perfect company if you are looking to start and get experience in mortgage and processing
Direct management is supportive and flexible 
Banking hours 
Good benefits (401K match, insurance, etc)
2 personal holidays, pto, bank holidays, sick days
Nice team members
 many different opportunities for growth
Pretty good work life balance- things can get a little stressful at times but if you talk to management or find ways to balance that, it is not too bad

COVID response from company- March 2020 everyone in my location started working from home. It was a surprise to Wells like all other companies however they adjusted really well and provided all the tools necessary to get the job done. They also provided some bonuses to employees as a "thank you" which was nice. Overall I would say they handled it better than expected.
cons: Pay- the pay is not bad however once you have experience they are usually not competitive with the pay and you can get a lot more at other companies. However, they have changed their structure around to be more competitive so unsure what it is now.

The shift bids and promotion goes to favorable employees and during meetings if u have a great survey itâs not recognized. Only favorite employees get that. pros:
Semi okay benefits
You MIGHT get to work from home after your three months of training is up IF theyâre still keeping people at home due to the pandemic. Otherwise, youâre stuck in a small cubicle.
cons:
Pretty much everything else
You donât get enough training and canât use that as a valid excuse for when you make any mistake
You will be audited twice every month when you get out of training and things begin to count against you. Once youâre out of training, you canât get below 97% accuracy a month (which equates to literally no mistakes because of the way audits are weighted) and if you fail your audits 5 out of a 6 month rolling period, youâre done. Thereâs no question or review as to how little your mistakes were or how nit picky the quality audit team was, youâre just fired. 
They keep raising the quality audit bar to make it almost impossible to pass every every month. Seems that they would rather fire people for âqualityâ instead of just laying off from a VERY busy department
A lot of management has never worked your position but will try to ârelateâ with you
Get ready to work a lot of mandatory overtime. The claim flow is so busy but they wonât hire enough

pros: I loved working this position at Wells Fargo. My supervisor was amazing and your work is based on individual as well as overall team performance. The best part about that is your team could be struggling, but your individual performance is also measured and taken highly into consideration for promotions. I was able to sit at my desk and plug away with limited distractions, listening to music was allowed, and there was the opportunity to work remote after the probationary period was over and it was shown that you could still maintain your numbers.
cons: My particular shift was 11am-8pm Sun-Thurs, would have preferred different hours and days.

review: Soso to much brand damage leaving everyone running with there heads cut off
pros: Very few... PTO, 6 sick days..
cons: Company is going down the drain. I worked as a banker for 7 years.  After the account scandal everything fell apart.. they no longer know what they are doing anymore. Half of all employees are new hires.. innocent employees have been fired over rumors of opening accounts with zero investigation. I personally left due to the many laws I saw broken and covered up. I once had a team member in dealers services hang the phone up and purpose not answer back after informing her of fraud taking place with her department and a local dealership... I live in Los Angeles very sad.. worst part a lot of the managers that did shady stuff are still employed.. lord knows how.. specially in Santa Clarita! My manager forced me to lie on my time sheet so I wouldnât get paid overtime... weâd get busy and she would force me to help and then throw the blame at me... donât apply here and sure as heck donât invest your money here! Also BONUS was reduced to nothing went from abt 3k a quarter to abt $400

review: Coming to work here was the best decision ever.
pros:
The culture here is phenomenal. The message is all about how the people make the difference and the company is very focused on developing employees. 

The routines set in place to reinforce the behaviors are phenomenal. Resources available to leaders for improving coaching style are endless! They have even taken external leadership theories and incorporated those into the resources and training available. 

Highly engaged and talented people work here, making it a great place to network and grow.
cons:
Some systems are a bit antiquated, but to be honest Iâd prefer that over flashy stuff that glitches out all the time. 

Time off is not very competitive, and it doesnât increase with positions that have more responsibility, it only increases with years worked at the company. 

No fully comprehensive health plan, but they do offer a company funded HSA with one of the plans.

review: A good start to get into the banking industry
pros: Definitely had a good time in the last branch I worked at. But it all depends on the people you actually work with. Just make sure you find the silver lining in any job and you will find happiness in it. Oh and also to get to the next step is like a banker is somewhat easy. Just have to be eager enough to put yourself on the map of your manager
cons: Only con is I wish they would have a better scheduling for part timers. Its either you come in or don't come in at all with the bank.

pros: They have the best benefits Iâve ever seen. Great health insurance, start out with 144 hours of PTO. You get 40 hours of PTO added at your 3 and 10 year anniversaries. You usually get holidays off, if not, it counts as a floating holiday that you can use later. 16 week paid maternity leave. They even offer paternity leave. Iâve worked with great people and managers. A very beautiful and diverse culture.
cons: Sometimes their training is too fast and they will throw you to the wolves and expect you to figure it out by yourself. Sometimes thereâs an inappropriate staff to manager ratio when your staff is brand new and have questions about how to do their job. Some departments are very micromanaged. They track your ever move, bathroom break, any time you walk away from your desk, etc. Sometimes goals are unrealistic.

They will replace you in a heartbeat.

They treat you like children, clocking your performance, even the time you spend in the bathroom. Job expectations changing daily sometimes from one hour to the next. You never feel totally in the loop. High turnover so you see new faces all the time. Very little chance for upward mobility. I know a few people who work here whoâve gone on to make decent money but no one wants to stay. This branch is a joke. Work somewhere else.

pros: The pros of this company USED to be the benefits, 401k, and the PTO. But you canât really take PTO when you need it, only when your manager allows you. So whatâs the point. Customers hate doing business here and employees hate working here. Canât run a successful business like that... sorry fear mongering will only work so long. Management sucks, youâre overworked like crazy, quality of life will suck, and everyone I know is quitting.
cons: Iâve been with the company for ten years and Iâve seen Wells Fargo get worse and worse each year. Managers are old farts that are not in tune and in touch with what customers and the younger generation wants. Managers are super conservative up tight people running the show and no one likes doing business with these type of people. If youâre single, with no life, and love being rude to people, work at Wells Fargo

review: Path To Underwriting at Wells Fargo
pros:
Company benefits are great. They pay well for the role. PTO ~18-20 days. This is the pre-role to becoming a mortgage underwriter at Wells.
Daily customer contact report sent by manager via email.
Work from home 100%.
Provided Dell monitors, laptop and equipment.
Autonomy for how you want to complete daily work.
Senior leadership making easier document process for borrowers.
cons:
Your job feel REALLY depends on what type of manager you have.
Have customers 30-90 days and keep in touch via phone/email ~5 days
Daily reports are run for outbound calls.
Everything is monitored - calls, emails, login time, inbound time.
Reports can be overbearing on you depending on manager.
Documents expire so re-request from borrowers.

pros: Some colleagues made it tolerable but over time it didn't matter anymore.
cons: The sad part is when I started with another bank which I will leave unnamed they were amazing. Then WF bought us out and that was when I discovered what being in hell was like. They put on the mask like they were changing the company for the good but in reality employees were overworked and underpaid. The turnover was higher then any other company I have worked at. This was due to a combination of things, one was that new hires were not given enough training to feel confident to do the job, others could not keep up with the fast pace, some realized that the sales part of the job was the entire job and was lacking the customer service we were supposed to be giving. Then you have others being termed for mistakes, a lot were probably due to lack of training and or coaching so instead of coaching the employees they normally just termed them. The growth oppt. was very little unless you wanted to go from a teller to a sales position and manager only if another leaves. Don't even consider lead teller because the salary was barely higher then the teller. I recall countless times were entire stores were being termed due to gaming. I also recall countless times were others were sabotaging each other. The leaders acted more like ditators then partners. They would work against you instead of with you and thought that talking to everyone like they were a child would gain respect. The sales goals expected from the employees in every position were so unrealistic and over the top that I can see why so many were not interested in staying. Most would go work at other banks altogether where they could focus on the customer rather than focus on what else they can sell to them. After so many years of seeing this all unfold I felt that being in an environment where everyone around me was so toxic was not healthy. The above things that I shared were not things happening to me, these were observations and when I see things being done over and over and nothing ever changes (even when we have spoke up about it) then sometimes its better to move on. I decided to pursue other ventures. Leaving that company was the biggest weight off of my shoulders ever. I hope that things have gotten better since then.

review: Run Away if you are US tech employee
pros:
They used to have the best salaries in the area.
Some of the benefits are ok.
cons:
Wells Fargo is flailing trying to stay afloat. It is now trying everything it can to get rid of as many US employees in technology as possible and replace them with offshore employees at a fraction of the cost. The pandemic has only made this trend worse.

The experiment started about 7 years ago. Two separate management chains, which only diverge about a level or two below the CEO. Offshore is completely unaccountable to anyone in the US, and their performance is abysmal. US employees take the blame for their mistakes and often have to work extra to fix them.

Wells has always had a bad time managing underperforming employees. Employees who routinely do the jobs of 3 or more people are never promoted or given raises, while those who do nothing climb the ladder quickly. With offshore, that is magnified 10 times. Most offshore managers only care to increase their headcounts, with no regard for actual delivery of work. The project I work on has steadily collapsed under their weight, as every US employee who leaves is replaced by 3 offshore employees who do literally nothing, if you are lucky. I have "coworkers" who haven't made a single check-in in over 3 years. They are being promoted.

What we are now seeing is most of the valuable US employees being given negative performance reviews, including those who have literally done the work of 7 people for more than 5 years. Management does not care. They have targets to meet, and they will meet them.

It is abundantly clear the Wells Fargo is moving to a 100% offshore technology model at the expense of its US employees. We get no bonuses. We get no new hires. They get tons of bonuses for no work, and always seem to have new job reqs opening.

It. Is. Hell. Here. I'm literally just waiting until they lay me off so I can get a severance package. I hate every second of this place and cannot wait to leave.

review: It was a fun ride while it lasted
pros:
The 10+ years at Wells Fargo have been both kind and unkind. Below are the things I enjoyed most.
The work is (mostly) meaningful, and sometimes treated as professionals by management. The people are technically savvy (some even smarter than myself, LOL) and really great to work with. I got along really well with most others, as long as we all focused on the premise that we are working for the same employer trying to accomplish roughly the same goal: building a better Wells Fargo one day at a time and one person at a time.
The pay is really good. Healthcare and related benefits are decent, but could be better. Paid holidays and PTO are satisfactory. Increasing PTO is a good way to keep employees. 401k matching to 6 percent is a gift, as was the ability to obtain an internal loan from the 401k balance was a lifesaver. 
The corporate cell phone and other technical equipment made the work more bearable. Although some years were considered "tight" and expenses were minimized or eliminated, having a corporate cell phone to separate personal and business calls makes all the difference. Also, having an option for a MacBook was much better than not allowing them at all (Thank you for merging with Wachovia Bank), and also allowed me to perform calculations and programming much better than the Windows laptops.
I enjoyed the 16 hours paid volunteer time, as well as matched donations to non-profits. Wells Fargo did a great job encouraging volunteerism and giving back to communities.
cons:
As someone with "disabilities", there were little accommodations that actually helped me feel like I was being heard, understood, and accepted by my immediate management. Instead, I was treated like a child until I raised my performance level, and was micro-managed for over a year, until laid off in December, 2020.
New upper management have raised several concerns and started workstreams/workgroups that will hopefully add some light at the end of the tunnel, however, it is a little too late for abuses that have already occurred and mindsets already set in stone. Despite the major abuses already discovered (2015 customer account abuses and subsequent regulation changes, 2009 Network Engineer burnout lawsuit, others), similar abuses still continue today due to the legacy Wells Fargo mindset to force employees to work until they burnout and leave, or are displaced at or above age 50. There are a few good managers, and most of the employees are awesome to work with, however, many have left or been pushed out due to lack of following with the marching orders.
There are no real career paths laid out, unless you want to become a political manager and move up the management chain of command. I and many others have suffered under this regime, and I have had little to no ability to move into the career path I really wanted. There was no time because I gave all of my energy and time to my day job, I was not given the opportunity to learn skills to move into the career I wanted to (no solid training courses or programs), and again, no tangible support from managers to help employees to grow.
Some of the new strategies from executive management are good, but several do not make sense for a majority of the technical staff, such as the migration to BYOD. Such strategies make sense for securing Wells Fargo assets, however, leave the employees out to fend for themselves. What about employees who cannot afford the necessary technology to perform their job? What about employees with little knowledge or ability to secure their home network?
Corporate technology that was paid for by Wells Fargo is increasingly watched and bogged down with security software to restrict and log every possible function, even if it is required by the job function or duties. Even my assigned MacBook Pro would turn the fan up and max out on resources on its own, or even crash the OS with no answers for many months.

review: This job isnât what it seems
pros: I got lucky and was put on a team with a supervisor and manager who listen to their employees and assist them in a helpful manner
cons: There is only one good manager. There is only one good supervisor. The training is minimal and doesnât cover even half of the job. When you request more training you will be denied. If you are a high performer, you will be overworked as under performers are not reprimanded or retrained. The job has an unnecessary amount of stress based on lack of information, guidance, training and some customers are horrendously rude. Nothing is cohesive. Process and policy changes are constant and you will be dinged by quality assurance regardless. New information is only sent via email, no additional training provided. You will not be compensated for being a high performer or working additional alert types that others do not.

pros: Decent salaries and great benefits.
cons: No opportunity for growth regardless of how well you're doing, no support from management, team members are disengaged, Mgr's expect you to work hard and sell products but doesn't compensate you. Management will only focus on your weaknesses even when you feel your strengths trumps.  No recognition, no motivation from management. When doing annual reviews they will only focus on what needs improvements to avoid giving you an annual raise.  Upper management expects the impossible from branch managers which creates negative working environments in the branch. Wells Fargo is changing to become only a phone bank/ digital institution. Branch team members aren't knowledgeable about anything bank-related and are required to transfer customers to outside departments, phonebank, or online instead of helping them in the branch. If you want a great banking experience DO NOT WORK HERE. WF has a horrible reputation and other banks look down upon WF employees as if they're crooks so if I were you I would avoid putting WF on your resume.

review: I hope they learned their lesson
pros: The branch in San Marino was completely contrary to all the articles you read about Wells Fargo. Branch management was great. This specific to that branch. Great team of people, still good friends with many of them. Great relationships with the customers too.
cons: All the things you've probably read in the papers. I worked for 3 branches total. San Marino is excluded from this. San Marino was amazing. The first 2 branches I worked for were awful. All the managers and regional managers we had to report to were the ones who created that toxic and untrustworthy culture. They all got promoted because of their high numbers. We all know how they got those high numbers. Snakes. They would fire people for not meeting goals. I got punished numerous times for that. Because I wouldn't game the system I would have to stay late and cold call people, work extra hours unpaid, even work 7 days in a row at the grocery branches. A pure slime way to "motivate" your team members.

pros:
-Benefits package
-Wells look good on a resume
cons:
-Cliquey management teams
-New company direction ruins a lot of career and development plans for employees
-Compensation lower than other banks
-Clear lack of vision from upper management, the bank is at fault for almost all of the issues/scandals that it faces.
-The company will have a major "focus" that it hammers into its team members for a few weeks/months, then drops the idea completely and moves on to something else. It's blatantly obvious that all of these ideas (Packages of change, change for the better, customer first, the recent complaints emphasis...) are just to appease some regulator, but the part that makes my laugh the most is how we are still failing to comply with the regulators' standards.
-If you are a motivated individual, I'd encourage you to consider other avenues. Because of the scandals Wells has faced in the past, there are no sales goals, which many employees have taken as "we don't have to do anything more than the bare minimum." It creates a disheartening work environment for those trying to get ahead.

pros:
Wells Fargo Home Mortgage (WFHM) is a great place to work for individuals with a background in mortgage and real-estate (such as appraisal, lending & underwriting, debt-collection, customer service, and business analysis), but it is heavily dominated by the paraprofessional class (i.e., those who majored in degrees that have nothing to do with banking or finance). In that sense it provides an excellent opportunity for those who have not had much luck finding work in their respective majors.

The Good: 

Wells Fargo provides great benefits for permanent employees and career-advancement for those who are dedicated and driven. WFHM in particular provides a relaxed environment to its employees and offers a great deal of independence (not a whole lot of micromanagement) in addition to sparing you from a lot of unnecessary hype, such as morale-boosting exercises and/or meetings.

In addition, virtually any mortgage experience on your resume carries some value in credentialing you for other mortgage careers.
cons: One mark against WFHM is that makes heavy use of temporary/contracted workers and does not guarantee that such positions will end in permanent employment. This means that you could theoretically work an enjoyable position for years only to find yourself jobless the next. Wells Fargo also has a 6-month obligatory waiting period in between contracts so you aren't likely to return to your old position after having been let go.

review: Some good people, but deep, deep, deep state of long-term employees holding it back
pros: Most of the people at WF work had and want to do the right thing.
cons: The culture is such that, historically, no one wanted to make a decision, so they just added staff hoping THEY would make the decisions. This has resulted in a HUGE amount of unnecessary employees that just make work to justify their existence. Hopefully, the new CEO and his cadre will see through the "DEEP STATE" smoke and mirrors and cut out a lot of the fat around the waistline.

pros: 401k vesting schedule is immediate, no cliff or graded vesting schedule which is nice because then you can take your 401k match money and run. PTO package is decent too.
cons:
I went through the licensing program through associate staffing. You get 1 shot at passing the SIE industry essentials, Series 7 & 66. Luckily for me I was able to pass them, if you fail any of these tests you will be let go from your contract. Once passing all the tests you will be interviewed for the role. The job is pretty much guaranteed at this point since they spent the money getting you licensed for the role. As most of you know already, these particular licenses enable you to provide financial advice regarding investments such as Mutual Funds. However, in this specific role youâre unable to give any advice. There are 3 products you get to discuss with customers which would be a Wells Trade Account, Intuitive investor, or offering a phone based or full service FA. The customer has to decide which of these options is best for them. As the licensed associate youâre not able to tell them what would be best, oftentimes this creates an awkward experience between you and the customer because theyâre looking at you to be the expert and know what would be best suited for them. The role is basic and becomes mundane fast. 

Expect to be taking back to back calls for your entire shift. 
Expect to repeat disclosures on every call. 
Expect your calls to be reviewed constantly and brought to your attention if you failed to state verbatim one of the 5+ disclosures. 
Expect to work Saturdays if youâre new. 
Expect to be in the role for a very long time, I was in the role for 2 years. I was constantly looking to get into an analytical role. Despite being in the role 2 years I was unable to interview for any other position I applied for internally. As for my colleagues they experienced the same problems regarding internal promotions. 
Expect your manager to miss all your 1 on 1 meetings. 
Expect to be a number and a droid. 
Expect upset customers, as most customers resent WFA for the scandals and disorganized client services group. 
Expect to regret the job you have chosen. 

On the final note I wanted to share the moment I was working Saturday in March 2020, when the COVID pandemic was on the rise and a stay at home order was issued by the NC governor. During work on Saturday a gentlemen in a hazmat suit showed up at my desk, informing me they would be spraying because someone in a nearby cubicle had been quarantined for being in close contact with someone who had COVID. My colleague and I, who were the only 2 scheduled at the Charlotte site on that particular Saturday were flabbergasted to say the least. My lazy employer failed to mention to us they were spraying the building that day for COVID. My manager asked me for a picture of the gentleman in the hazmat suit, I took the photo on my cellphone sent it to my boss. He told us to leave immediately and that we would be compensated for a full day of work. Later my boss calls my personal cell on my time to tell me the photos I have taken were illegally obtained, since I took the photos on private property. He asked me to delete the photos and call any of my family members I sent them to, so they could also delete them from their phones. Unbelievable, right? 

Anyway donât work for this company, anyone who currently works there in the ICC contact centers will be in my prayers. Perhaps, all departments arenât bad, I just speak for the ICC contact centers AKA call center.

Every other call, my TL would pull me off the phone and ask me why I didnât provide a service such as a second savings account. I would explain these people canât afford to put money in their current savings with a balance of $10. How are they supposed to manage another one? Fees people! The company wants to eat customers up with Fees. I absolutely hated it. Iâm sure their are other portions of the company that are good to work with but as long as there is a sales goal, you will have issues.

pros: Salary, flexibility. My manager is nice, but he doesnât really know anything either, not faulting him here.
cons:
Iâve worked here in the department for less than 10 months. My department has been transitioned to 2 other departments since starting. This means Iâve had 3 roles since I started, which is incredibly unorthodox I believe, but I do understand Covid made somethings different. It wouldnât be a big deal except every time Iâve been âtrainedâ for my roles with WF, there has been almost ZERO training.  Even my manager doesnât get trained or seem to know things. The job itself is fine, but talk about stress when youâre asked to do a job after literally 1-2 hrs of training and thrown new customers every day. I was in a call with my bosses, bosses, boss and when a question was presented with concerns about the constant transitions, they were told âHLPâs are here to execute leaderships goals, thatâs the end of it.â After hearing that response, Iâve never, ever felt so much like a number and my opinion as employee is not cared for. I definitely have learned that if you work at Wells Fargo you do not get to express ANY concerns and if you do management makes you feel like youâre in the wrong for bringing it up. 

When it comes to the work itself, not anyone else seems to care about helping the customers than The HLP and HMC, who are bound to the underwriters schedule to look at anything. Customers are always disappointed in WF lack of concern on purchases/refinances. 

Also, there isnât really any additional benefit given to employees who get Covid other than STD. Many other companies allowed you to take time off or made schedule adjustments for those with children related to Covid issues, but  not WF.

review: Decent Pay and Benefits, Not Worth the Friction
pros: Good pay, good benefits, good PTO
cons: If you are working in operations, don't count on job security or even basic human rights. You can't even go to the bathroom without scrutiny. If you are working elsewhere it might not be so bad, but Wells Fargo is so hard to do business with. They are such a high friction company, and what I mean by that is that it takes 4 forms and a blood sample to link a brokerage account and a bank account. It takes a minimum of 14 business days to have a simple transfer-on-death account reviewed, only for it to be rejected 90% of the time for the littlest thing. Usually something along the lines of putting a middle name when they only needed a middle initial. Everything is an extreme process, that gets handled by teams that would rather reject it than help you complete it.

pros: WF has great benefits. They're very helpful when setting up your benefits when you're a new hire. They value diversity--so if you're bilingual, your chances of getting hired increases. Their 2-weeks training program is exceptional. When I was first hired and told there was a mandatory 2-week full time training, I thought it was too much, but it really prepared me in the best way before they put me in a drawer by myself. Because WF was just under heat because of the scandal when I was hired, in my year and a half there I got two raises without asking for it because they increased the base-pay for everyone. Now, it's much higher than when I worked there.
cons: Unfortunately, your direct manager will have to tell you to do things that they might not agree with, because the person above their manager and so on told them about the changes. It's a huge corporation and you have to remember you are the bottom of the barrel. However, even though you're the bottom, you are expected to provide 100% excellent customer service because you are the face of Wells Fargo.

pros: Great benefits, especially for veterans or reservists
cons: Iâve found that few people, at least on my team, ever progress to higher roles. The few that have progressed were in their roles for 10+ years, and promotions seemed based on seniority rather than merit. There were many outside hires for higher level positions. When I requested consideration for a transfer to another role with higher pay in another department, my manager refused to give me her blessing, stating that my role on my current team was too important for me to leave, and that the team would struggle to replace me.

Additionally it seems to be the culture to not take ownership of issues. When a question is asked I always feel like I am on a scavenger hunt being passed around from one contact to another. pros: Excellent benefits / prices for benefits ; in my location, there was room to advance - saw many people promoted from within; the underwriting software had some positive attributes in that it did a great job of dropping correct automated conditions with less editing than I do in Encompass ; pay was fair ; ability to work remotely a few days a week; regularly held underwriting meetings to keep abreast of policy changes. Decent PTO and holidays. Management generally let's you work flex time - I am not a morning person and generally didn't get to work before 9am. My manager never gave me a hard time about it as long as I got 40 hours in. Bonus was about 10% of my base as long as quality was good. Also I felt that quality control was generally pretty fair in their reviews, although others disagree with me on that. Overall I was appreciative to have this job.
cons: Not able to get your DE unless you worked in a particular physical office in 2 states only; lots of regulation impact on employees - such as, not allowed to use excel (seriously, and if you were caught using excel worksheets you were in trouble), random mid-year in-person interviews by internal auditors; training was rough - not enough access to help when needed and the corporate trainor didn't even know how to use the lending software - sent us back totally unprepared ; they use a program called "core" for underwriting and it is glitchy (for example, when the last condition is cleared the loan will automatically CTC itself. So let's say you cleared all uw conditions, but the title and appraisal were not in file yet. Those come in later and get cleared by the collateral review team. Without any warning, your loan issues it's own clear to close status. This causes you to miss anything new added to the loan before the loan gets audited by QC. Also, once a loan is in CTC status it can never be moved back. So if the loan suddenly isn't ctc anymore (let's say documents expired), it will stay in CTC status, making it hard to manage your pipeline/be aware of the true status of a loan.  Also- the system "recommends" a document to be attached to a condition and people overseas will attach conditions at 2am. (Processors don't really process here, they just resubmit loans when they see that the system recommended a document to a condition). No control at all over what processors do. Underwriter essentially becomes the processor much of the time. Finally, exceptions to credit policy were painstaking to request. Long turn time to get a reply and the system would lock you from making any changes, including canceling the request! This was very annoying.

pros: A lot of benefits like a 401k and health/dental/vision insurance. The hourly wage is pretty competitive, especially if you're looking for a college job. Managers and co-workers are very nice and easy to get along with. You learn a lot about the industry.

pros: PTO, flexible schedule for part-timers, tuition reimbursement. You get the opportunity to meet cool customers every once in a while. It's a foot in the door to the financial services industry.
cons: (Pre-Covid) This role was very stressful for what little you are compensated. You're on your feet all day and have to juggle multiple responsibilities at once to succeed . Extreme micromanagement adds to the stress of giving good customer service while following risk and compliance procedures. Management is obsessed with getting perfect customer survey scores and will always find something to criticize you over. Although the infamous "sales goals" were technically abolished, you are still expected to sell products and refer customers to bankers. High turnover, most people simply move on from burnout or because management prefers to promote people with long tenure over education at the retail level. Post-Covid was a nightmare that made all of the problems above 2x worse.

review: Toxic micro-managers and disengaged, arrogant CEO
pros: Pay is above average for role.
cons: Benefits are terrible, toxic management that micro-manages everything. A totally disengaged CEO that re-labeled 'Team Members' to 'Employees'. This was not just how he addressed people. Any documentation that referred to 'Team Members' was changed to 'Employees'. He rarely communicates with his employees, and has shown that he is not capable of doing anything except condescend (see recent remarks regarding black executives) and cut jobs. WF is also moving all their risk, compliance and technology off-shore to India. Already 3,000 American jobs gone.

After the first or second year of gaining experiences work can get repetitive with the same objectives. So you'll will grow a lot but only up to a certain point in retail, and then after that it's just like hitting a brick wall. After the new ways of Wells Fargo has been put into place in the past few years they promote less often.

review: Not what it used to be
pros: Employment with reasonable benefits and PTO
cons: With the terrible management policies in the last decade the chickens have come home to roost. The key imitative of Scharf and his management team is to get Wells out from under the asset cap and return Wells to the black. This means endless hours of work and cost cutting. This has made it very difficult as an employee, but don't believe there are any 'better' options. I'd not recommend working at Wells Fargo until the asset cap is removed and they are back to a regular dividend.

review: Finance Opportunities at Wells Fargo in SF: Few and Far In Between
pros: I feel I am compensated fairly, and the people I have worked with at Wells Fargo are extremely helpful.
cons: They are replacing almost all the upper management in the bank and there is a lot of change in the organization. It is hard to keep up with and I have been working longer hours recently. In addition, Wells is hiring non-customer facing finance positions in cheaper cities, so there aren't many finance opportunities in SF. If I want to stay at the bank and have opportunities to move up, I'd probably have to move.

review: We, both as Team Members and Consumers, deserve and should demand better.
pros:
The man who first hired me then resigned for personal reasons. A good Boss is always most important.
Clients that you meet and have an opportunity to build professional relationships with. 
Good formal training program.
cons:
A seemingly Product of the Month, Widget Sales approach, not Relationship based, in spite of a claim otherwise. Micro management from Regional level to the point of what amounts to an unnecessary, unethical and unprofessional behind your back approach to inspect by asking direct reports about their leadership, which in turn, tears down a Managers ability to build a team, a business, or hold a team accountable towards the right behaviors. An approach that compromises Branch Management as well as overall Team cohesion. This is done, in experience, due to personal insecurities or vendetta of an unqualified Regional Manager, not based in business need or fact .
Any successful organization will tell you that once talent is brought on, allow that Leader to work, to bring his/her respective skills set experience and value to the table, instead of breaking them down and (attempt to) churn them out, be it by burnout or under some false guise. Again, in my experience and conversation with others, former and current, this is due to personal insecurities, nepotism, and/or to place fear in others so that they may be controlled. We've all seen how this approach has impacted Wells Fargo recently.
A few cancerous employees who may have a following but disrespect new talent while actively participate in unethical account opening, playing part in the now well known illegal account opening scandal.

pros: At the time of hire, there was structure to the analyst training program. You would fly out to San Francisco, Minneapolis, or Charlotte (depending on your office location) once a year for training. At the end of your third year, if you had successfully completed the analyst training program, you were able to go through âCMTPâ, which was also an in person training program designed to mold analysts into relationship managers or portfolio managers. This has since changed to virtual courses to cut costs (this all occurred pre-COVID), where youâre essentially paid an analystâs salary to take online classes... looking back on things, there are better training programs (or entry level positions out there.
cons:
Constantly changing management hierarchy (commercial banking).
Lack of company culture and vision.
Pay

review: Worst HR I have ever experienced. MUST be able to take blatant verbal and physical abuse.
pros:

Mental Abuse Prepares You For Intense Wall Street Environment
cons:
Unhealthy Management At Most Branches
Expensive Health Insurance
Manager-Backed Human Resources

CEO Says Insensitive Racist Remarks (but the Mgrs say worse)

pros:
big company benefits that are expected
my biggest pro was that the location I worked at was extremely convenient for me
only real reason I stayed
cons:
Big company problems. From lower to higher management the entire company is CORRUPT. Work abuse, favoritism, intimidation, bias/racism... you name it

They mask it all very well by providing every employee with bogus corporate training and videos that make you believe you're in a safe work environment but you're not. They try to give you the time to take them all but no one ever does because they'd rather use that time to do other activities that help them either keep their job or keep from getting written up. The way they approach development and issues with your work is patronizing. Every meeting is just a series of questions that lead to another question that eventually lead to an explanation of how you're incompetent as an employee. They didn't say it, you say it, so its an HR friendly of telling you you suck, work harder. When you do get something right they pat you on the back and say nice but how come you didn't do this ALSO. The fear of lower level employees drives the lowkey intimidation all of management know they have. Everyone is SCARED to speak up in fear of retaliation. Then the company falls back on the most bogus no retaliation policy that comes way of those useless trainings and videos I mentioned before. So you speak up on the fact retaliation is still happening despite the policy and then the company hides behind an HR department that's suppose to protect you. HR is an absolute joke. Opened several claims to HR even in groups involving half the team members to no avail. Every answer back from them was a professional and corporate friendly way of saying, "we understand and empathize with your problem but we don't agree, deal with it." or "we understand we're going to talk to upper management" then upper management sides with the people you have a problem with because they're buddies. 

Ridiculous work expectations and performance that's globally expected due to the intimidation factor and complete lack of confidence and support. You will feel overworked and absolutely dread or fear coming to work 

Don't make any last minute or even 1-2 week plans in advance you have to ask for vacation 4 weeks in advance and still hope it doesn't interfere with anyone else's schedule

Sunday off but 2nd day off is completely random 

Don't even get me started on the WORST commission structure of all time. especially now that they're apologizing for opening fake accounts. And whatever commission you make gets paid 3 months later, what a joke. 

Lastly depending on your location a certain ethnic group will most likely dominate the work place even up to higher management so you'll experience racism/favoritism to some guaranteed degree if you're not part of that group. But remember they'll mask that too and keep it under wraps with those same bogus policies and a PHENOMENAL HR team. Sarcasm implied*

pros: Wells Fargo treats employees very well with benefits and salary. Minimum wage has been raised significantly in recent years and has greatly improved customer relations after the sales quotas were removed. Further, they have been very proactive at keeping both customers and employees safe with the COVID-19 outbreak.
cons: The reputation of Wells Fargo is still stained and many customers hate the stigma. While many policy revisions have attempted to stymie this reputation, nonetheless the reputation lingers which makes it difficult to admit working there. Further, with reduced focus on sales, instead Wells Fargo is making many small cuts and revisions to reduce the loss of income. Many such revisions frustrate customers, such as not allowing cash deposits to other people's personal accounts.

pros: Great benefits, decent salary. Great training, it's a good place to get started in finance, especially if you are willing to learn.
cons: Getting things done is a bureaucratic nightmare. Everything has to be approved by many different groups or people. If something goes wrong you can't just fix it. Often different departments in the company have no idea what's going on. Also they they try to make it sound like upward mobility is easy and can happen quickly. I've found half of that to be true. The jobs aren't difficult but they do have minimum time in job expectations that make it really difficult to move on in some instances, most aren't policy related either. Just a company culture expectation managers have an attitude of "well I wasn't able to move on for three years so that's what I expect out of people in that position." It can be very frustrating at times.

pros: Generally friendly co-workers, great opportunities for non-WF new hires (external hiring appears to be the focus), many opportunities for people who like to fix things, new leadership sees that significant changes are needed.
cons: Leadership driven changes are not practical in the timeframes laid out. Current systems, data and lack of widespread automation do not allow cross linkage of information. Large investment in data infrastructure and connectivity between systems and hierarchies/taxonomies is desperately needed to support desired changes. Work arounds are being created in Excel to meet leadership direction rather than robust solutions such as connected databases and reporting tools (Tableau).

review: Poor Leadership from CEO down. Hard to allow the Contact Managers
pros: Paid time off. The very few Contact Managers and Line Managers who actually care and have a passion to develop their bankers. Paid Maternity leave of 16 weeks.
cons: With poor Leadership from CEO down itâs hard to allow the Contact Managers that were born to be leaders and be the very best career developers shine. The ones who who actually care and enjoy their job developing said talent that the CEO spoke of. They get lost in all the negative press that Wells Fargo will forever be branded with and for good reason. Wells Fargo is deceitful to itâs customers til this day. Employees are overwhelmed, overworked, under appreciated, undervalued and underpaid. ER solution is horrible and doesnât protect employees. These Contact Managers and Line Managers build relationships with HR to get away with anything and still be covered, no matter how unjust their actions are when a banker opens an HR case against them. Wells Fargo also is handling a certain hotel credit card and arenât informing customers. If customers knew they would close the cards. So instead we answer the phone, Welcome To such and such and Not Wells Fargo.

review: Its not the worst but not the best either
pros: Rollover vacation a lot of job options if you are lucky you get good management I did the second time. I also am glad that during world crisis happening you can count on your job being a stable source of income. They do try their best with employees but remember not every district is the sme.
cons: hard to tranfer/promote I have literally had to argue for my promotion and its long over due. They make it difficult for you to literally do anything and are very picky. The recruiters are not good at having a sense of urgency either which is another issue I don't seem to understand why they act like that. I cant even move up to a new position within the company unless I have permission even after I have made my time in position! Also not all districts are the same which makes it harder to understand the culture and values because everyone is different.

review: Dishonest,  Incompetent and Out of Touch  Direct management
pros: Benefits, PTO, Insurance, Ability to Transfer to another team
cons:
The most ineffective, dishonest, un-empathetic, direct management I have ever the displeasure of working with, who would rather cause workers thrice the time to do something, then provide them with full information or the tools they need to do the job. Or they "command" them in a way that causes direct harm to already built stakeholder relationships. "Because I say so," went out in the 1980s. This guy does not like men or women, but it is obvious that he favors women even less than his male direct reports.

Out of touch with reality or flexibility as the firm undergoes an enterprise wide Agile Transformation.

Thank goodness I was able to transfer to another department. 
My new manager respects their all their staff, freely sharing information, encouraging, empathetic.

review: Is not a good moment to join Wells.
pros: It is a good company with good benefits as any large organization. A lot of your daily work life depends on what type of manager you have. In my case this is the only reason Iâm there.
cons: At this moment WF is going thru changes and higher leadership doesnât look like they have an established course of action. They tell you one day âthis is what weâll doâ next day is all different and they act like the previous order didnât even existed. Also the district manager is a complete idiot. Not sure where did they find this guy but he had to be friends with someone because no one knows how he got there. At this time I would wait to join. Maybe in a year or so. A lot of decisions seems to come from people not really involved with implementation. Seems that they are paying lots of money for âprojects managersâ that donât have a clue of the projects theyâre managing.

review: Great culture, little guidance. Iâm still committed!
pros:
-Wells Fargo loves being a part of the community theyâre in through volunteering and free financial education outside of the branch.
-They still have traditional bank services and features like actual tellers with the option of digital for customers based on preferences.
-Changes are made off of customer and team member feedback vs. company goals. 
-You are able to be the best version of yourself as Wells Fargo allows diversity in backgrounds,thoughts, and ideas which supports our diverse customer base.
-If you consistently work hard, you will be noticed and rewarded no matter how incompetent your manager is!
-Benefits are good, and there are many options available.  New team members start with 12 or 13 days of PTO, 2 personal holidays, and 2 community service days in addition to regular bank holidays.
-The top priority managers teach their team is to focus on the customers need through understanding whatâs most important to them and not the bank.
cons:
-Middle management is a joke and half.  My District Manager stays at home 4/5 days a week and managed by emailing reports. I think I may see them once every other month which is not supportive of my career development. Unfortunately, this a trend from market to market. Iâm not sure what happens when someone becomes a DM... someone need to look at that.
-As a Branch Manager, it can be difficult to complete your responsibilities due to staffing issues that never end. Itâs hard to be upset, because most of them move to different areas or get promoted. Itâs just really hard to get a posting for a new position. 
-Our teller and banker systems are outdated. They have errors and delay customer interactions on a daily basis.
-There is no sales incentive for doing well. More times than not, a branch that has large volumes of customer traffic will always receive higher payout than smaller branches.  The customers literally come to those branches to apply for accounts. They way the incentive is made, branch balance totals are adjusted so frequently that you never understand if your branch is actually growing!  This makes it difficult for a manager to motivate their team to exceed customer expectations each day. I see where theyâre coming from.. why work harder when theyâre going to pay you incentive for just coming to work LOL.
-The pay structure is silly. Like May companies, they make salary decisions based on how easy or difficult is will be to retain you.  So if I live in an area with less jobs equal to mine at other companies, they have a lower risk of me leaving and pay me less. If I live in an area with a lot of competition for my skills, they pay more. This causes team members to get paid less for the same job someone is doing in another area regardless of their work ethic. Raises? 1% if you perform, 2% if you exceed, 3% if you do some type of sexual favor for your boss if you can find them after they give you keys to the branch. Iâm kidding about the 3%. Thatâs too generous for them. 
-The training has become the worst Iâve ever seen at a company of this size. When I first began in 2012, they taught more in-depth material that allowed you to come into the branch with a basic idea of what youâre doing. Now, my team members come in the branch with two weeks of questions to ask. Unfortunately, the manager has to then choose to do their tasks or support the team member by actually training them. Of course I choose my team members development which leads to extra hours in the Branch for myself after close for everything else. 
-I feel appreciated by upper management, but itâs lip service most of the time. I think they expect my direct manager to do the leg work to make me feel valued and thatâs missing completely. After numerous positive customer reviews, the recognition I receive is only based on me teaching other people how to achieve the same business results. Can I at least get a breakfast muffin? Or even an empty bag with an imaginary muffin? Ok, well letâs start with a thank you and go from there  :)
-Geez look at the time - by now you may be thinking Iâm a disgruntled employee, but Iâm not. I just feel the bank could support areas better than they are and meet the commitments they strive to meet with their team members like they attempt to do with customers.

review: Awful place to Work-welcome to the world of political correctness. No job security
pros: Pay is adequate as is PTO
cons: The biggest issue is job security- it doesnât exist at Wells. Every year you will anxiously wait to see if your position or line of business is to be eliminated. Wells Fargo recently hired a new CEO. The new CEO is pandering to the liberal PC crowd by intentionally âletting goâ quality leaders to immediately fill those roles with token diversity hires. Wells Fargo has become a politically correct nightmare. If you are a white male- steer clear- they have made it now that you have privilege. In addition, the new CEO has bent the Q2 Earnings to for his narrative, showing higher than actual loss(by booking future projected losses that have yet been realized). This is an effort to support sizable layoffs  that will occur q4 2020. Wells will use these layoffs to support a false narrative of their new an improved diversity ratios(which didnât occur by hiring well suited minorities, rather by firing large amounts of existing non- minority team members)

Bleeding inefficiencies
Overly rigid ie, often use one size fits all when it never does
Nothing cutting edge about them... like I wouldnât at all be surprised if we start rolling out a TQM approach next week. 
Thereâs fear building

Despite all of this, I would love my job again with a different manager.

review: So inefficient, So many hidden errors; Dysfunctional HR
pros: Work life balance and flexibility of working at home is great; Slow moving and easy to keep up; Leadership focused on regulatory requirements. Finally change!
cons: Inefficient; Limited potential in HR if you are a straight white man; Errors everywhere; Doesn't embrace formal change (shotgun approach); Charlie is being beaten down by the culture (no stopping WFs ability to "clog the drain" every time and make everything more screwed up than when they started. Charlie is pushing so hard to get the regulators out of our business that many are white washing the problems and kicking the ball down the street. Let's just say, I am NOT a Wells Fargo customer! Tried to be, but the mortgage rate was the highest alternative (even with a TM discount), the processing time much slower, and the process more complicated. And, based on my experience working at WF, they would have made mistakes.

pros: Wells Fargo was a great company to work for. I like all their upper management and was able to enjoy the people I worked with. The hours and tasks were very fair and there was always scheduled coaching and training. There was great PTO, sick time and benefits including maternity. I only left because I graduated college and my career field is public health not banking. Overall I loved the corporate setting and the professionalism of everyone I met. This also includes similar ways of doing things from branch to branch. Nothing is perfect but overall I had a wonderful experience working for Wells!

pros: Iâve been at Wells Fargo for 1 year already and I love the atmosphere here

pros:
- My immediate team is great. Some typical dysfunction, but for the most part, 5 stars for my team.
- Work/life balance is excellent - laptops are closed by 5pm at the latest (only rarely are there extraordinary needs that require after hours work)
- Incredibly diverse team, lots of women in leadership roles (at our level, anyway, not so much 'upstairs')
cons:
- Upper management is still resistant to approving full-time Work From Home, even with Covid-19 and a CEO who is remote from NY. Some folks are not being approved for FT WFH, even for jobs that have been done remotely for years now. 
- Conflict-avoidant culture... As reported in the press, serious problems and bad behavior still not directly addressed and allowed to go on for too long.
- Old, institutionalized, dinosaur mentality (mostly 'upstairs') and fear of change. Lots of old white guys in charge, so... yeah.
- Under-performers and folks who just won't do their jobs can easily hide, the org is so large. And because conflict avoidant, these problem folks are never dealt with.
- Salaries are below market for design jobs. Raises don't keep up with inflation.
- The process to get any little thing done is arduous and time intensive. There are so many groups and systems involved, it's redonkulous.

pros: Big company with a big name.
cons: Not a lot of room for being independent. Compliance is doing their job, but often at the hindrance of employees being able to do anything positive. For example, we abandoned a client/prospect event because Wells basically told us we couldn't do anything that would enhance the experience for attendees.

pros: Worked with my school schedule
cons: No cons for this business

pros: You will get experience at a large organization that works with some large clients
cons:
Th he organization has a large number of problems that make it impossible to do your job and enjoy being at Wells. They are as follows:

1. Management: The people in charge have created such a toxic culture that anyone you would want to work under or with leaves within 1-2 years. Many senior RM staff are simply there because they cannot find another job and will make your life very difficult. Throwing underlings under the bus is a regular occurrence and promotion is based on politics and desperation to get someone to stay that has told management they are leaving. 

2: Career Development: There is none unless you are extremely lucky. Trying to move to different groups will often not be allowed and management can deny your transfer for any reason. After this you will be marked as not âloyalâ and you essentially have no future. Few, if any of the things you will do will be transferable to real finance jobs so your time in the position will be viewed by other employers as little better then unemployment. Trying to better yourself through school or programs such as the CFA or CAIA is highly discouraged and can lead to outright retaliation in some cases. 

Pay: You will be paid 25-40% less then the same job at other banks and will be paid 30-50% less then what you would make on the principal side in a finance position. Bonuses are reserved for those that feed managements ego so expect to make only 10-25% of your bonus potential no matter how well you preform.

review: One of the better places I've worked
pros: Lots of paid time off, great company culture, and lots of training/coaching if you want it. Company also promotes from within and regularly checks in with you to see what your goals are with the company. Management will work with you to help reach those goals. Pretty good worklife balance, you work your 40 hours and very, very rarely overtime. Company actively doesn't want it. When on paid time off, management never reaches out in regards to work and you don't take work home if you're not management.
cons:
Likely due to past scandals, policy changes at a very rapid pace. It feels like you constantly have to check to see what the new changes are and calling the back office can give mixed results. Coaching can become overbearing if you're not used to it.

Sales goals technically eliminated, but it's still ultimately a sales job. This isn't so much a con, but different managers will have different expectations for this aspect of the job.

review: Used to be a nice place, but...
pros:
When I first started:
-Flexible hours (could work 9-5, or work a 4-10 schedule)
-Managers expected results but treated us like human beings
-Work culture was fairly balanced
-Managers were transparent in departments goals and expectations, which made it easier for us to work and obtain (we consistently met 97% SLA monthly all over the country).
-Entry level pay was fairly competitive

When I left:
-Team came together, but it was due to us relying on each other to get through the day.
cons:
By the time I left:
-They laid off our sister site with little warning, despite our departments doing very well
-They strung contractors along for well over two years before they got frustrated and left; they were dedicated and reliable workers, and new contractors were a mixed bag.
-In my last year, we changed over multiple managers; I believe our immediate manager tried to shield us from a lot of things, but upper management pressed hard, which trickled down to the Processors
-Micro-managing. We were only allowed seven minutes the entire day to use the restroom. As the bathrooms were on the other side of the floor, one visit took 3 1/2 minutes, running. 
-Work environment became toxic, and by the time I left, the turnover rate had been rising.
-Managers no longer were transparent; goals changed frequently without warning, and upper management became obviously disdainful of the Processors when we didn't meet 100% SLA (our team worked with appraisers all over the country, and most of the time if a report didn't come in on time, it meant the appraiser had trouble or just didn't bother doing the report).

As my former coworkers told me, my department no longer exists as it used to.

review: Some managers care, others really don't
pros: Work life balance is good. I have worked with great team members and have been able to build my customer service skills. It's a good job to start out especially working through college for the paycheck and experience.
cons: Some bad management and even more terrible ones. There are branch managers who were apart of the sales scandal and act like those sales goals are coming back. They constantly degrade, but don't help you with your growth or assist with building a plan to help you reach the next position. They want to take credit for the success their team members make in the branch, but haven't done anything to reach those goals. Constantly getting threatened to be written up for something minor, because they can no longer threaten to fire over not cross selling enough. 8 was never great for the account holders who have a below to mid average income. WF says there's no pressure to sale products, but threaten to close and shut down branches for not generating enough revenue. The health insurance is terrible and the best compensation really just goes to BM and DM.

pros: Good, smart, hard-working co-workers. Good technology with helpful tech support. The work can be very interesting. Good benefits package. Some work- from-home flexibility, depending on role and location. Could have been a great place to work, in the right department.
cons: First, there was the stigma of working at Wells, even though they kept trying to put the negative recent history behind them. The management team in my department treated us like children, even though most of us had extensive experience in the work force. There was no training on the processes when most of us came on board, and processes were constantly changing with no training on the new processes, so we had to figure them out on our own. Then when management didn't like what we did, we would get chastised for it and penalized. There were constant threats and intimidation tactics used, and unrealistic weekly deadlines. There were also threats of senior management taking away the work-from-home flexibility, even though it worked very well for most of us. Most of us were working a lot of unpaid overtime, and there was no flexibility in our work hours, even though we did not work with the general public. The turnover in the department was fairly high, and I learned pretty quickly why that was.
