pros: Not much honestly.  Given so many companies are just as bad, WF is not alone.
cons:
Where to begin.

Countless certification classes have to be taken, and I mean countless!  Most have nothing to do with your job.  They are long and mind-numbing.

Apparently WF tellers have to be told how to be ethical...sad.  Perhaps HR should do their job.

Speaking of HR, I donât know if we even have an HR department.  Well, unless you count the Diversity personnel.  What do they do exactly????

Donât expect anyone to be helpful.

Donât expect documentation.

Donât expect training.

Expect a lot of temps...I mean contractors.  And donât expect them to have good hygiene.  I would be shocked if one of them washed their hands in the restroom.

Expect every IT request to take forever and donât expect it to be easy.  

Very old school mentality.  People cling to the past and fear job security.

If you have the misfortune of working in IT...youâll know what Iâm talking about.  The Operations Center takes business casual to a whole new level.  I didnât realize stained sweatpants were business casual.

Take the job if you enjoy the cons...there are plenty.

pros: They won't lay you off if they can help it, they'll move you to a different department if possible.
cons: Literally everything else. You'll be fine if your manager likes you, but 1 bad manager can destroy years of work. And you will be moved and you will not have a choice, so it's just luck of the draw if you have a good manager or not. The training is poor, and the only way you'll get support outside of training is if you're lucky enough to have a helpful senior employee. And they will tell you to do things you know are wrong when you get into production so you can try to reach their insane goals.  Probably why they have so many lawsuits all the time. They will tell you there is a bonus structure and then do everything they can to make sure no one can reach their goals to get the bonus, which is why their employees ste worked to death and constantly stressed to their max. Room for advancement is limited and managers can block you from applying to different departments for ANY reason. Really.  ANY reason. Think of what that could mean if someone has some arbitrary issue with you? It's an incredibly toxic work environment and I watched more than one person reach their limit with Wells Fargo in my 7 years with them. It isn't worth it & leaving was the best decision I've ever made for myself and my family.

review: Good benefits, pay and room to grow
pros: Company does care about employees and offers a competitive pay, PTO, 401k etc. They come through in times of needs such as a natural disasters.
cons: Busy days such as the first of the month can be hectic. Lots of work and a lot of room for error as a teller. You need to know how to focus on keeping your cashbox in balance and minimizing risk for you and the customer.

pros: Good pay and bonus for good work. Interesting subject matter and excellent management support but that is highly dependent on your business area.
cons:
1) It takes an a tremendous amount of time to get a small amount of work done. Any change requires multiple level of approval, usually by people who have no idea technically what the change does or it's implications.

2) Hypocritical messaging regarding changing behavior for fixing ethics issues and customer abuse while still exhibiting dubious legal behavior.  

3) Some senior developers hide information and resist on-boarding efforts of newer developers to make themselves more valuable. Sink or swim mentality. Assume you have the same knowledge as another developer who has been there for 20 years. Constant use of acronyms and system names in the presence of new employees without explanation so as to make comprehension more difficult.  

4) Absurdly cumbersome processes that have no value. For some reason most seem to think this is acceptable and even engage in enforcing these processes.

5) Can take weeks or even months to get the development tools and access needed to do your job but still expected to get the job done without those tools. 

The list goes on....too long to list here.

cons:
Give you a very short leash. Upper management expecting you to hit certain loan volume numbers while your branch manager does not allow you to go out and meet business owners or give you blocked time to make outreach dials. As a "specialty banker" you should NOT have to do certain things (replace debit cards, stage direct/be a greeter, let customer in safe deposit box) which occupy your time, YOU SHOULD HAVE TIME TO MEET WITH HIGH NET WORTH CLIENTS!! Your direct manager will say to business leaders what they want to hear but will restrict you from doing what you were hired to do.

Not clear on incentive payouts. Continuing to change payout structure and not sharing what numbers are above average, average, below average.

Loans take forever to close. A lot of closings get missed due to the slowness of processors/underwriters. They have very little motivation to move loans quickly.

The base pay is laughable.

Boring repetitive work, you barely can advance without doing it for a year. The woman showing me how to do work was skipping tons of things and not using quality. review: Come here to take a step back in your career...
pros:
The pay is fairly good. Contributions to HSA for doing Well-Being activities (annual physical, biometric screening, etc.)

Apps System Engineer is a generic title for various disciplines of Software Development from SW Engineer, DevOps, SDET, etc. All are paid roughly the same depending on grade level.

The CEO is doing his best cleaning up the mess from past events and has a good reputation in the industry.
cons:
Cons greatly outweigh the Pros as you can see from the upcoming rant.

Benefits aren't that great. Still have to pay for the high deductible plan and contribute to an HSA. The deductible is also much higher than what I used to have elsewhere.

Constant reorgs. I accepted an offer, then about a week before my start date the team I joined was put under a different group of which the Manager has no idea why the team is reporting to him! I have not worked on a single thing since I was hired... NOT A SINGLE THING. The reorg has nothing to do with it though, the project pipeline has no future insight. They work on a single project until it is done and THEN decide what the next project is.

SLOW!!!! The team I joined says they've been working on the same project for 3+ years! Everyone that works here seems to be stuck in their old ways, they aren't open to adopt anything new. Skype Audio Meetings are literally just becoming a thing here and no one seems to want to adopt it for some reason, this is a decent example of how far behind they are in terms of using modern technology. They would rather dial in from a VIOP phone AND join a Skype Meeting to view what someone is presenting. Makes no sense to me why no one wants to add audio to the Skype Meeting, it's simple. I'm mind blown by this.

TONS of restrictions. I understand with it being a bank and all, but software that you can install on your system is very limited, no modern technology, all old legacy stuff. You'd think modern tech would have better security vs legacy. Hard to research and learn a topic or simply find a solution to a problem since almost every single site is blocked (except for StackOverflow THANK GOD).

I left a job where I was valued (but underpaid) and worked with tons of other smart engineers for this. Thought I was coming in to be in more of a Lead role and was more motivated than ever. Now I am demotivated, twirling my thumbs everyday trying to keep myself busy....

I could go on and on but I'll stop here. Would not recommend coming here, especially if you're in Tech. Not to mention the bad rep from historical events of which I figured they had moved on from.

pros: Great benefits including health insurance ($60ish biweekly for me + children with a $6500 deductible, no copays for regular visits), dental insurance ($15 biweekly), plus other options to include 401(k), life insurance (up to 10x salary), plus you start out with 18 days PTO and after two years you get to 23 days PTO plus 8 paid holidays including 2 personal holidays. Also PAID leaves of absences that don't come out of your PTO balance - critical caregivers leave (up to 5 days), primary caregiver parental leave (16 weeks), secondary caregiver parental leave (4 weeks), short term disability (6 weeks), long term disability, etc etc. The benefits are why I haven't switched to a job closer to home.

review: company that does not care about their employees
pros: they have decent benefits for employees
cons: they do not genuinely care about employees

pros:
Monday thru Friday day shift schedule, good location, nice cafeteria.










































On the plus side, it's Monday thru Friday, a regular schedule, a full if pricey cafeteria, lovely grounds to walk around on your lunch break, and fairly good security. Some teams are much better than others.
cons:
Wells Fargo at this call center only hires new CSRs through employment agencies, so if you accept this position be prepared to make $13.50 to $14.00 an hour for the same work that your "official" Wells Fargo employed team members are making $19 to $25 an hour to do. If anything, you will work harder, because all the calls not requiring "special handling" will get routed to you. You will take back to back calls all day every day, while your team members chat about their lives and weekend plans. And I know, "I get paid either way", but sure not paid enough.
We are promised a good chance of being "hired on" after a certain amount of time and proving ourselves as valuable employees, and finally attaining the job security, pay increase, PTO, vacation days, sick time, and stock options, but believe me, it's just a carrot on a stick held in front of you to make you give maximum effort for minimum compensation.
Why are they paying agencies big money to bring us in, full background checks, FBI fingerprinting, eight weeks of paid training, and then hiring only one agency person on in the past 6 months? Because there is a possibility this site may shut down in the next year or two, and all agency employees aren't going to need that severance package, right?
And good attendance, people skills, and work ethic won't get you hired as an official employee, you have to market Wells Fargo products. "It's not selling stuff, it's 'having a conversation' ". OK. After the Wells Fargo scandals over marketing products, (Google it if you don't know, I had to) you would not think you'd have to sell stuff to people who call in with concerns about keeping their homes to get hired here, but you do. If someone calls in looking to refinance, sure, but if someone calls in and immediately launches in to "why weren't my taxes paid out of my escrow?!?!", and there's a note on their account to try to sell them another mortgage, it is held against you if you don't do it! The survey system is ridiculous, their opinion of your service is lumped right in with how the customer perceives Well Fargo. The American people don't trust or respect Wells Fargo, and you are not paid enough to try to make the overpaid bosses look good. As an agency employee, you will be treated differently, all my fellow agency employees will back me up on this. Left out of team potlucks, generally left to our own devices to figure stuff out, reminded snidely to "call Robert Half, or Dysis, or Sparks" or whoever your employment agency is, if a customer recommends in a review that you get a raise or a compliment. If you think your agency pay is in anyway compensation for what you'll be doing, think again. If you think you're so awesome you'll be hired on within a year, think again.

cons: Significant issues in 1) hiring external consultants as Product Managers but treating them very differently than internal employees; morale is low; 2) HR system has huge issues - employee's voice is not heard, feedback is not taken and managers have way too much power; this is proven in the consumer sales scandal 3) polices and procedures are lack of control; this is also proven in the consumer sales scandal 4) qualities of employees 5) career opportunities are better in San Francisco, but not in Charlotte

pros: Lots of customer interactions keeping things different each day.
cons: Unfortunately, the formal training offered by Wells Fargo corporate does not prepare you sufficiently for the start of the job.

pros: Good company to gain valuable experience and for career advancement.
cons:
The company's official goal of reducing the workforce by 10% through corporate restructuring has displaced tens of thousands of loyal hardworking employees, myself included.   

Also the company's reputation has taken many hits over the last 3 years.

pros: Pay, benefits, insurance, training, coworkers

pros: Relaxed environment, not breathing down your neck as long as you get your work done

review: Great interactions, supportive management, opportunities for growth. Tons of federal rules and regulations to follow.
pros: I love being able to meet so many different customers. I love problem solving so the persistant customers are my favorite. There is room for growth and advancement and access to benefits that are above average in my case.
cons: So many employees so it can be hard to be seen. You need to be able to advertise yourself for available advancements. Always changing rules according to regulations so it can at times seem unstable on what what to follow.

review: Moving Up Can Be A Pain
pros:
The pay is decent. 
The work is relatively easy. 
The benefits are good, especially the PTO. 
Scheduling is manageable.
The people are typically cool.
cons: Moving up is a lot about who you know. Promotions are heavily influenced by Branch managers and District managers. If they don't like you or even if they don't know you too well, you're not likely to move up as soon as you could if you actually knew them.

pros: Enjoy working with the good environment
cons: No cons in my list

pros: Able to gain to gain skill working at the bank and a lot of opportunities to get promoted.
cons: Managers will often show frustration and take it out their team during busy times, many risk management you have to learn. Customer are always right! You have to do whatever in your power to make the customer happy even though you did everything you possibly did.

pros: Manager engagement , work life balance and ability to apply for jobs beyond your band

pros: Many schedule options. Room for growth

pros: Great maternity leave and parental leave benefits. 5 weeks of PTO per year not including national holidays that are paid as well. This is a job to use as a steppingstone, its a great opportunity to increase you finance knowledge. You will gain alot of confidence specially if your young and hungry.
cons: They donât pay you for speaking an additional language even although Texas has a huge demand for spanish speaking and Vietnamese speakers. If you have teller experience they will exploit your non paid skills to work both in the teller line and as a banker. Several days a week you will be the only bilingual associate and will be taking two to three times the workload and you assume all risk both in losses with your register and approvals done at the teller line and not to mention the risk you assume opening consumer accounts. They came up with the title of business advocate to avoid paying you more but having the same responsability of a PB2. A PB2 does the same as a business advocate only that position actually pays you bonuses  and a raise in your salary. We get alot of days off but have no money to do anything unless you live rent free with your parents, which in many cases its the norm.

pros: Benefits are decent, nice part time job opportunities.
cons: The branch level seems to not be highly valued by corporate. The pay was not that competitive, if you seek to career development and advancement support is minimal and not based on MERIT.

review: Stay away from retail banking. Death Row for your career.
pros: Good benefits, bank hours, okay pay
cons: Wells Fargo has lost direction since their scandal. New rules, procedures on monthly basis. No clear goals. Retail branches barely have products to offer.

pros: Leadership is receptive to good ideas. Valuation industry is changing rapidly with technology. While adoption of some cutting edge technology is lacking, the process to adapt is thoughtful with quality valuations at the center of decision making.
cons: Can be slow to change when an organization is this size. Also consent order results in extremely careful risk management, which is good, but time consuming.

pros: Work managers were good. Customer service was good. Training was good
cons: Little pay. Not much time off. Hours were sometimes really long.

pros:
Days went by fast

not a stable schedule

pros: good pay i didnât mind it

pros: worked with some great people in a great atmospher
cons:
Pay was 100% commission but you received a draw that you had to pay back out of your commission checks. Once you get behind after a bad month or 2 in a row it is almost impossible to catch up. Any deal that you do get you are going to be fighting tooth and nail to get it approved by underwriting.  you will spend more time trying to close current deal than finding new clients.

But part of it was I just wasn't ready for that kind of job at that time in my life. I was fresh out of college and did not put in the work and effort it takes to be successful in that business.

review: Great company experience and learning environment.

pros: Close team, always together working , Learning new material,

pros: I recommend to most young people interested in business to apply to Wells Fargo. I have learned a lot about the financial world as well as banking through working here. In my experience, there is always a chance for upward growth. The job is very structured and I have always felt like there is a good support system around each branch I have been at.
cons: Wells Fargo is constantly changing, and that can be a lot to keep up with. Keeping up with small tweaks made to the policy is usually not too hard, but recently there has been a lot of larger changes that effect  how the day to day work flow feels.

review: Company in need of culture change

cons: Senior management makes it hard to do your job effectively as a manager. The culture of the company has turned into one that does not care about its employees. The hard work that you put in day in day out goes overlooked. For career advancement senior managers hire who they want not based on the most qualified candidate. If I was not for the people doing your job would be unbearable.  You are over loaded and the pay does not compensate.

pros: holidays off , including Sundays are nice

middle managers are horrible. they lies all the time because they know you can't talk to senior management.  if you do,  they give you an warning as insorbodination.  
I really got sick of my manager's lies.

cons: The pressure to constantly perform at a higher and higher level all the time without the volume lead to burned-out employees.   WIth such pressure focused on production,  it was really hard to take advantage of any of the many programs that were offered without causing irreparable harm to our production expectations.

pros: Work life balance is good but comes at expense of compensation.
cons:
Work in WIM as an equity analyst. 

1) Sales organization that puts sales over investment outcomes or fiduciary obligation to clients. 
2) pay is poor vs other bulge bracket firms. Firm generally pays below market rates & raises are below inflation. 
3) tech systems are archaic & channels are overly bureaucratic. (Takes months for compliance approvals, 4 weeks for website access for primary job function)
4) Upper management is more interested in cutting costs to get their bonuses than well being of employees or providing living wage
5) Investment management division is disorganized & a âfollowerâ. Competitors far more innovative.

cons: Internal Audit is a strange mix of very young people and some seasoned individuals.  Frowned upon if you want to work from home even though all meetings are virtual.  Been working there for over a year and have not met my manager, the people on my team, nor the business partners who are audited.  Flex cubes are a nightmare.  Parking is atrocious and expensive.  I don't recommend working here.  The young kids right out of college have no idea how a real world working environment is.  No one even says good morning.  All glued to their laptops.  Very unhealthy environment.  Other departments are not as rigid.  Just very strange atmosphere within internal audit.

cons: Large company with lots of politics. You can't move your line of business to easily, so whatever you start at is where you will stay.  they make up coaching and try to fabricate effectiveness through quick and baseless observation. In the past, they used fear as a huge technique.  Most of the managers and personnel are there in some capacity. HR is robost, Change comes only from the top down.

review: The best job I've ever had
pros: I loved working at Wells Fargo. It may have been because I was at a great branch with awesome coworkers and managers, but I always felt right at home there. Customers could be difficult sometimes but my boss was always there to back me up. The company is also pretty good, I did enjoy the efforts on team building. They also had a great PTO plan and benefits.
cons: I think they could improve more with the salary though - they give a menial raise each year which only ends up being an extra 30 cents or something. I did enjoy the efforts on team building and such.

pros:
They really care about you as a person, not just an employee
They are supportive and understanding when mistakes are made, but work with you to fix habits
They prioritize hiring from within, so there is room for mobility
cons: A big contributor to employee experience is the branch or service manager- I was lucky enough to have a great branch manager, others were not so lucky

cons: Some aspects of corporate management appear to be out of touch and distant. Corporate culture can make you feel like a number at times.

pros: They give you an opportunity to pursue your licenses.
cons: Management/HR are very deceiving when it comes to the licensing program. They tell you they give you a 60 day window (2 months) to study and take the test. They also say be sure not to study on your own time or have any overtime because they will not pay you outside Monday-Friday within operating hours. What they dont tell you is, they dont care for you to pass, they really cut short your time by counting the days by calendar days not by business days. If you don't feel ready or prepared to take the test they will not allow you to extend the time frame, and the PassPerfect program you utilize is mandatory. They will not expense for you to use Kaplan or any other service. Studying for a Series 6,63,65 takes a lot of time to study for and FINRA allows a 90 day window just to prepare and study for one exam.

pros:
Managers are trained to help you succeed and develop a career path and help set you up to exceed. There are many training platforms that you can take if you wish. You can job shadow in a different dept. to see if its what you really want to apply for. There are no longer any sales goals. They are rated by reviews and putting the customer first. It is a very customer sentric company now. In the retirement center they were fantastic, understanding of any learning curve new associates have. You are helped by teammates as well as management. The amount of time my manager spent with me was shocking compared to other companies. You actually looked forward to them stopping by instead of dreading it. You are not yelled at for a mistake at all. I Love this company. I only left because my boyfriends father got leukemia in Arizona. I can reapply and come back, but I am moving.

Their benefits are spectacular. in addition to your PTO they also provide you with 2 additional days to use on personal holidays for those of us that celebrate other holidays, you also get 2 more days to use for volunteering (can even be to supervise a school trip with your kid!). You also can use your PTO whenever you want, it does not have to accrue (Unless you quit and have used more than you have technically earned, then you have to pay back what the difference is, obviously.) I can't say enough good about Wells. I was Anti-Wells and pissed at them for a long while. They have really turned around!
cons: FMLA with any company only covers blood relatives or official in-laws.  The data entry dept is still (personnel mentality wise) is still stuck in the dark ages. They yell at you, you are not allowed to talk, very goal oriented and if you meet your daily goal early in the day, you are automatically handed more work and then made to stay late. I do not suggest Data entry at all for wells fargo. I loved the work, but the team in that area alone was torture. I barely made it a year (you have to stay a year before you can transfer out of the department).

review: Avoid the TMT Group - especially in New York City
pros: As you can expect they have some smart analyst, some of the VPs are nice, and Directors were good as well.
cons:
This is one shop you should avoid at all cost if you just got an offer coming out of undergrad or business school. The head of the group uses fear to 'motivate' people and belittles people due to his own insecurities - you won't see that while they try to sell you on the company. 

 Many people have quit or changed groups to avoid him; even his most senior staff need to pretend to get along with him.  There are a couple of people that because they're good at their job, they keep them around but are horrible to work with (Fin-Tech). Run for the hills. This place will give you PTSD if you stay too long.  Experienced some dislike and I assume it's because of my cultural background. They hire lots of wealthy conservative southern white men who haven't had many interactions with people from diverse backgrounds. Take that as you will.

review: Decent job, extremely hard to move within
pros:
Work life benefits are not bad you do have the support of a giant HR department in case you have an issue like scheduling days off, health benefits, HSA, 401k support, ect. 
Giant company with lots of opportunities
cons:
Very hard to move laterally. Since Wells Fargo relies heavily on Contract to hire roles for most of it's roles it makes it hard to move laterally in the company. 
Here is my breakdown on why the contract to hire model is a very very poor tool for Wells Fargo. 

1) Most Staffing agencies will ignore your resume or not work with you because that is considered poaching

2) Those same staffing companies will in turn hire outside talent that are generally not familiar with Wells Fargo software, policies, or have experience.

3) Existing employees are never given the opportunity to move laterally since the roles they want are being filled by staffing companies so they in turn get frustrated and quit.

cons: Wells Fargo does not care about its employees or customers.

-Great team environment. Teammates reach out to you almost all the time, so communication and problem solving was always smooth. 

Honestly, it really depends on which branch you're working at or who you're working with. I  was lucky to be working with a great team, because I've seen other branches where it things were still great but didn't go as smooth. 

Also, even though I was a student working only 20 hours/wk, Wells Fargo offers benefits, PTO hours, and is very compliant with employee policies, so that was nice. If I were to choose a place to work after retirement, it would be here.

review: Unprofessional and Behind on the Times
pros: You get to meet really cool people who also hate the job as much as you do. There's free food sometimes and events.
cons: The customers are wild because Wells Fargo enables them to be. The management makes decisions that if they were actually doing your job, they wouldn't make. They are behind technologically. Their app does not have a lot of things. They do not pay enough for what they make you do. I was a regular phone banker and they made us all go through online banking training which is another set of skills. For two weeks you were trained then thrown on the phone with those new set of skills with the SAME SALARY. That was crazy to me. I had to spend longer times on the phone for I was doing more trying to troubleshoot for customers and was making the same amount of money before learning the skills. That's terrible. They don't listen or care about their employees. They will bribe you with food if their surveys are low or you seem unsatisfied. I also do believe Wells Fargo is related with money laundering for sure and they foster an environment for their customers that enable them to stay poor. Their app does not have an ending balance after each transaction just at the end of the day after the transactions post so customers are always irate for the overdraft fees they get a bunch of them.  Worst company I ever worked for never felt so uninmportant.

pros:
1) You get 18 days of PTOs and two personal Holidays for the first two years. Afterwards, you get 23 days of PTOs and two personal Holidays. You get more PTOs once you work for the company for more than 7-8 years. You get 4 months paid for maternal leave.
2) There's a backup daycare service eligible for team members. I have a little baby and I use this benefit whenever my babysitter isn't available. You can use 20 days of backup daycare services per year, and I get to pay just $20 per day for one child (company pays for the rest). The daycare I get to send costs $2100 per month if you send him/her full-time. 
3) Great management - My district manager, branch manager, assistant manager, and service managers all care about my growth & development and my well-being at the same time. I feel truly blessed to work with great team members. 
4) There's no sales goal , which means less pressure. All we have to do is helping customers based on what their needs are, and never force them for any product that they don't want.
cons: 1) We get paid less than how a personal banker at Bank of America or Chase does. I have friends work there, and their base salary is higher than Wells Fargo's (of course because they have sales goal).

review: Good place to learn, donât get stuck though
pros: Great way to pick up skills for entry-level workers, good benefits, lots of learning resources, decent pto, thorough training
cons: Retail banking career path is misleading and lengthy if youâre looking for a job at corporate headquarters.  May take you years of developing completely unrelated skills for the company to start moving you towards your actual goal.  By then, a decade later, you will be halfway into your career, with no relevant skills to your goal.... not ideal. Not to mention, the goal posts move... a lot. Also, BMs and DMs explicitly care more about what you can do for them and their district, rather than what they can do to develop their talent.  End up hemorrhaging their best employees constantly as a result.

pros: There are some hard working employees
cons: No management support. Refinance loans take 3-4 months to close. Underwriters are so worried about getting fired for making a bad loan that they try to kill good loans rather than to find ways to make them work. Interest rates are .25% higher than any other company. Loan processors are buried so they don't like talking to customers.

pros: - The goal of the organization is to help consumers and businesses succeed financially, and this is something that employees can feel proud of.
cons:
- The marketing organization has shifted over the past 3 years - it is now extremely process oriented. As a result, all programs, projects and campaigns take 3 times longer than they used to. The "process" is extremely inflexible and inefficient.
- Continuous layoffs in marketing has lead to poor work/life balance as the work of those leaving is given to others who already have more work than they can handle. And often the work that is transitioning to the employees that remain is higher level work, however, there are no changes to compensation or job levels.
- Constant changes in marketing processes and systems have created a lot of confusion within the marketing organization - ask 5 different people a simple question about one of the process steps and you'll get 5 different answers. 
- Due to the scandals over the last few years, risk, compliance and legal reviews are extremely challenging making it all that more difficult to get the work done. This coupled with all the process makes it extremely challenging to find joy in your work at WF, and makes you feel as though you are set up to fail.

review: Great Benefits but Don't value loyal employees
pros:
-Good Benefits- 401k and matching 6%, Health- all type of plans from low to high deductible, HSA- employer contribution of $800 if you do health activities, 16 hours of volunteer hours,  tuition reimbursement, generous PTO time plus 3 days floating holiday
-Lots of opportunity for internal promotions and they love to hire within
-Located everywhere, generally flexible on locations near home
-Direct managers are accomodating and supportive
-TOP dollars awards for department
cons:
-Pay for internal employees. They do not value loyalty. A person working in the role for 10+ years will never see any more pay then their annual "cost of living" pay which is below the market, they give you 2% yearly. If you get another internal job offer they can't raise your pay more than a certain % (normally no more than 10%), whereas if you were an external candidate, you can come in with the mid pay and surpass the loyal employee who has been doing it for more than a new person joining. 
-They advertise the mid pay on all their openings yet do not pay anywhere close to that amount. Because everything is considered a "lateral" move to upper management when it's not. Like coming from a regular staff to becoming a manager of a dept is considered lateral so they don't have to pay you the mid or anything more. They need to reasses what lateral means. 
-Poor senior management communication
-Too many levels of management to get an approval
-Too compartmentalize, there's a person for every single thing, so you get a lot of, "we don't do that" and then transfer to another department and then the same thing happen. Home Office does not take any accountability.
-Lazy and incompetent home office staff located in St. Louis.
-Uses offshore India and Phillipines, language barrier and makes a lot of mistakes, and don't understand some things. 
-Complaints or suggestion system for "excellence first" goes no where.

pros:
The bank has been extremely well positioned to take advantage of its size and with new leadership might finally fulfill its potential.

Allen Parker (interim CEO) seems to be doing his best and hopefully the new CEO will be able to change the culture at the bank.
cons:
Current senior management is lacking.  There is a lot of talk about "People as a Competitive Advantage", but little true follow through.  

Additionally, the hard driving sales culture still exists with leadership being all sales or former sales.  Management seem to be enamored with the sales persons skills at selling and buy in far to easily to the slick talking team members.

Additionally, I see the most truthful, honest, and dedicated people either leaving or being pushed out.

You do the exact same thing day after day for no reward or positive reinforcement. On top of all of this, the biggest clown of all of them is the department head- EV - this dude is an absolute idiot. He has covered up so many scandals and lies through his teeth. I would not be surprised if we see him in jail this time next year.

pros: They still have a few good people.  Used to be an amazing culture and place to work.
cons:
Scandals, bullying, downward envy and cover-ups from the top down.  Budget cuts are laying people off or squeezing the life out of those left standing.
I went there at 23 with pink hair and a clean bill of health.  I left at 35 with PTSD, Major Depressive Disorder, and a general anxiety disorder that continues to haunt me.

The company is on the being of collapse.  

I reported Disability Discrimination and Retaliation from my direct manager to her managers on 15+ occasions over 11 weeks until I finally had to undergo medical leave for severe mental health conditions.  I began reporting Retaliation began 34 weeks ago.  I opened a case with HR 21 weeks ago.  The investigation has gone on since May with no action taking other than relieve my manager of her duties.  The company refuses to take accountability for their actions.  I left specifically because of my managerâs behavior and her managers covering unit up.

pros: I have really enjoyed my time at Wells Fargo because our teller team is awesome and I enjoy going to work everyday. The pay is amazing considering what other banks in the Amarillo area pay their tellers. You have the oppertunity to earn quarterly cash bonuses up to $350 which is also nice.
cons: However we have had several full time teller leave the bank and instead of hiring me on full time they keep hiring other part time tellers. This has been very frustrating because I have a bachelors degree in finance and I'm not moving up like I would hope. I would also say that Wells Fargo doesn't really care how much school you have completed, if you have a bachelors degree then you would move up the same as someone who doesn't.

pros:
- Vast amount of career development opportunities due to the number of businesses.
- Good place to start your career and learn financial services inside and out. 
- Positive change happening inside the organization to create a better bank for the future.
cons:
- Worked in several lines of business within Wealth and Asset Management. Culture was toxic in every office. Coworkers, managers, directors all looking to move jobs (internally/externally) which destroyed the morale of my teams. Was very difficult to enjoy the workload when your leaders are focused on getting out rather than creating positive change within the business. During my 4 year tenure at the firm Iâve had 11 managers due to the high turnover. 
- Low pay; constantly trying to nickel and dime their prospective hires. 
- Very segmented businesses; makes it difficult for clients to work with us (improving, but still difficult)

pros: Competitive pay and benefits, current challenges present opportunities for those of monumental tolerance and patience.
cons: Wells Fargo's is an extremely challenging environment and culture. Egregious lacks of processes and controls create an environment fraught with uncertainty and a management and workforce that is generally hesitant to excel or challenge the status quo unless instructed to do so. Too many senior leaders in the company that have been in the same group or role for far too long, resulting in an elusive and defensive culture that has been extremely challenging to disrupt. I understand some of this has been improving over the last year as much of the dead weight in middle and upper management is being challenged or pushed out all together.

Many mortgage careers are simply started at Wells Fargo, so don't waste your time and head on over to a company that will value your presence.

review: working as a part time teller
pros: Easy job, decent pay (would be better if it was full time), opportunities for advancement.
cons:
Having to wait 6 months to become full time, the branch I was at made part time tellers work EVERY Saturday, they can be really petty about attendance... if you walk in 60 second late they might mark you tardy... of course that depends on your manager.  

This might not be considered a "con" to most people, but if you're a male depending on the location you work at they might make you wear a tie everyday... my location was very strict on the way men dressed and super lenient with women.

review: Culture of CYA and passing the buck
pros: Most lawyers are personable and non-competitive. Benefits are fine.
cons: Extreme sensitivity regarding risk ends up making situations worse than they need to be. A good common sense approach is often overlooked. review: Good opportunities if you follow their framework
pros: Good people, very good work-life balance with lots of community engagement opportunities, most folks stay for 5+ years
cons: The brand reputation is still "not good enough" following the scandals and employees aren't happy with their annual raises while EVP's continue to enjoy the lifestyle of $7M+ houses in California and tout "strategic alignment". Opportunities for advancement are limited and it takes a LONG time to go through the HR cycle. Many issues are based on the fact that many folks come from the small rural banks that WF bought a few decades ago. Those folks now have tenure and decision-making power, but may not have the global experience or mindset for innovation.  Initiatives take years (decades?) to complete. Some processes are very antiquated because the bank is so big. Basically you may need to drink the WF Kool-Aid to grow professionally, and that may come at a cost to your own timeline.

cons: The training the company requires doesnât apply to 60% of the employees within company. Zero training for current role. Itâs very corporate. A lot of re-org, itâs common to have multiple managers within 2-3 years. No commission for employees that are not sales but are required to work with customers and provide products to customers. You will never reach bonus potential due the companies compliance issues.

pros:
Fairness:
- Salary equality. Smart compensation system is based primarily on job responsibilities and geolocation.
- Ample opportunities for lateral and upward career advancement.
- Open support for gender equality. Met many other women and LGBT people who felt supported by the company and loved their jobs. 
- Excellent benefits.
- Making an honest effort to innovate and improve.
- Truly diverse (intellectually and ethnically) global workforce.
cons:
- Some old, ineffective corporate structures remain.
- Large company, which means that certain policies are not applied uniformly, even if upper management makes an honest effort. 
- Should do more to prevent the types of fraud that came to light in recent years.

review: Stressful Job and Will Ruin Mental Health
pros:
-Lots of paid time off
-Decent pay
-Benefits like 401k and paid volunteer time
-You might get one of the few good managers they have
cons:
-Ridiculous metrics, especially Average Handle Time. They care more about you having quick calls than actually solving the customers' problems. They tell you in training don't worry about AHT because the customer experience is more important. But once you get out of training, if your AHT is high, which is normal, you will constantly get nagged over it and micromanaged. AHT is probably the most important metric to them because they say the company spends millions of dollars in operation costs every second you're on the phone. But if you don't completely solve the customer's probably they'll have to call back and take up more time. I've had managers give us tips for how to get customers off the phone before they bring up another thing they need help with so that you can meet the AHT metric. Bad business practice.
-They sell you on the bonus you could get based on customer experience surveys. But even if you do really well in that, you won't get it even if your AHT is a couple seconds too high or if you had a QA dock and you're even a point off the requirement. But the rest of your team will still get a bonus based on the team's customer survey scores including your scores in the average.
-Even if you get a high score in your schedule adherence, your ability to solve the customer's problem on the first call, high customer scores, high quality assurance scores, etc, if your AHT isn't perfect even if you've brought it down, you won't get any reward and very little recognition.
-You get some good customers but you'll get a lot who scream at you, cuss at you, personally insult you and your intelligence, etc. and the company does little to prevent these types of customers from calling in and treating team members that way.
-There's very little flexibility to actually help customers and I agree some policies aren't fair to them. Those are tough calls to take and you get them a lot.
-No time to breath with maximum nine seconds between calls. Back to back for 8-10 hours. If you get up to use the bathroom outside of breaks it affects your schedule adherence. Every second of your time is micromanaged and you start to feel like a child and it's hard to regroup after a call.
-Too many coachings. At least once a week, but can be multiple times a week. They  will also plug in and listen to your calls while you take them to coach you, which is very stressful and inefficient. The occasional coaching and performance review is good. But too often starts to feel overwhelming and like a punishment. I don't know any adults at their job who are coached that often.
-Sometimes you will get a cool manager. Sometimes you will get one who micromanages worse than most and tracks you down to remind you to go to a meeting instead of trusting you to be an adult and check your own schedule. They will make you fill out unnecessary forms about your calls as you go through them. The will move you around on teams so if you get a good manager, don't get too comfortable.
-If you go to a manager needing help for something with benefits, leaves, your schedule, etc, they will either give you incorrect info because they don't know much. Or they won't help you at all and claim there's nothing they can do for you when they can.
-We once had a meeting with our manager's boss to give anonymous feedback. Beforehand said manager complained about anonymous feedback he was given previously. After the meeting, he talked to each employee individually and reworded the comments as questions to figure out who said what.
-If you have advice for how something can be done better or how they can help you to do your job better, they won't listen to it because they "have to" do things the way they are
-This job will ruin your mental health and make you anxious and drained all the time. You learn that rude customers aren't making it personal, but hours of that a day still drains you and makes it hard to focus. This makes the pay not even worth it between that and the micromanaging.

pros: You will get paid less than your competition. Managment will also default to the highest producer, regardless of what guidelines or rules were broken. If you drink the kool aid and pretend like everything is okay when itâs not, you could move up if youâre not in a sales position. You will have to relocate to do it. Not many opportunities to stay in the same region to move up.
cons: Completely unethical. Management bullies advisors to cross sell, even when itâs unwarranted. They push advisors to bring clients into the Private Bank even though clients donât want to. Management does nothing when people break rules, encourage people to stay quiet. I anticipate there will be more WF negative news for years to come. Managment lies to recruits to get them to come. I watched they say anything they needed to and never followed up. They are so big, they just trust you wonât be able to do anything anyways. They want revenue first.

review: Starting pay is low, incentives suck now
pros: Fun environment, learn alot about banking, and helpful when trying to financially get ahead and can help with other career paths outside of Wells.
cons:
Starting pay is weak compared to other competitors. 
"Bonuses" are a joke. In the year I was there, they lowered the amounts every single quarter because they got caught with sketchy sales practices
Bonuses are also based on how everyone performs so you can bust your butt and everyone else gets payed even when they didnt do their part. High school projects all over again. 
If your district plays favorites, good luck trying to move up. Nothing is performance based, all about who likes who.

It can be difficult to advance depending on the district you're in and management. The pay can be great, but isn't as competitive as other financial service companies with positions doing less work.

review: Tout Mentoring but Do Not Promote
pros: Commensurate pay, 401k options, bonuses, Flex Time, work from home options. You can end up with an awesome tight nit team to work with.
cons: Technology Sr Management promotes âhire inexperienced people and train them up!â But then flat denies any promotion requests regardless of employee merit. Only options are to wait for an opening at a higher level than you are then apply for it along with everyone else.  Promoting someone to fill that open slot is not allowed. That doesnât fit with the mantra of keeping talent in-house. MAJOR org shift is happening with a business strategy and  location strategy rollout. Expectation is that there will be zero to minimal Work From Home by Q1 2022. Cost cutting measure are being heavily implemented to curtail any remote work. Adopting AGILE methodology to all aspects of Organization.

pros: Great training that will help you go far in banking
cons: Lots of discrimination and favoritism. Lots of sexually harrassment known by management. Men make bets on  which new hire they can take down first. Again management is aware of this. Have to kiss butt or be personal friends to get a chance regardless of your work ethic. Pressure to sale to customers but they like to call it financial help to avoid getting in trouble by the government. Management will try to fire you if you get on their nerves or challenge them. New hires get paid more than workers who been there for years. You wont get more than $.50 cent raise a year regardless of how good performance is. Customers tend to survey the bank when they get asked to do survey on reps and even when managers listens to call and find rep did a great job the rep will still get disciplined. This will result in a bad performance metrix. Get in trouble for going to the restroom to much.  Not enough time to pump if breastfeeding. A lot of people scared to speak up on serious issues due to not being considered for promotion or being treated unfairly.

review: Good bank, good people, trying earnestly to regain its tarnished reputation
pros: Right after the financial crisis of 2008, Wells Fargo was considered "the best" of the big banks, with its reputation and customer service seen as better than its key competitors. In 2016 unfortunately, there were negative sales practices that came to light; this had a significant negative impact on the bank's reputation, its team members, and its business. Because of this, the bank has really tried to do an extensive audit of its practices, incorporate all necessary controls, and make customers whole. These actions continue until today, so most of the bank's initiatives are still geared toward's fixing what is wrong. The company has struggled with costs, process improvement, driving consumer growth, and corresponding lack of morale among its employees. I think the company's core is good, and is sincerely trying to improve. It has, and will take more time for it to regain a positive reputation among customers.
cons: It will take time to win back customers' trust. Most of the initiatives are not around marketing but risk mitigation and process controls

review: Good People and Good Place to Build A Career
pros: There are many opportunities to learn and develop a career in variety aspects of business, L&D, sales, management,  analysis, etc.
cons: The silo'd nature of a large organization.  Wells Fargo's reputation  has been hit hard  due to the unethical and misbehavior of key executives and employees.  However, this is not an indicator of the other 80-90% of the organization.  I was there for 19-years, and experienced high standards and ethics in the groups in which I worked.

pros: Good salary with year end bonuses which varied depending on your performance evaluation. 401K and medical insurance coverage. Good vacation allowance. Wells has upwards of 130 PMs managing their real estate portfolio across the nation. This group is known internally as Corporate Properties Group PMO, not to be confused with another group within CPG, the property managers. The PMO handle all new TI build-outs, ground up building and remodels. All retail bank work is handled by a select group of the PMO, while admin and other bank groups are typically handled by the balance of the PM's within the PMO group.
cons: Learning the internal software system was difficult and training was hard to come by.

review: Wells over emphasis on unrealistic work loads.
pros: When I first started (9 years and 10 months ago) work loads were manageable and training was impeccable and thorough. Expectations were achievable and clients were the primary focus. Customer service was everything.
cons: Truly disconnected and overly mico-managed.  Clients expectations and needs remain secondary to the whims of an overly aggressive and unsupervised risk department. You will be expected to work excessive hours of 10,11 and 12 hours days. Anything less will be reflected as poor performance in your annual review. Human Resources is non responses.

pros: Great Benefits, Salary fair, chance for advancement
cons: Stressful environment, health benefits are  expensive

pros: Great Benefits, Salary fair, chance for advancement
cons: Stressful environment, health benefits are  expensive

pros: Generous PTO, health insurance  benefits
cons: High turnover.  Low morale.  Narrow focus on 'metrics'. New hires are  very young with no experience, OTJ training thrown to the wolves.  Seasoned administrators are overlooked for promotion.  Most team leads are 30 or younger.   Lots of chatter and socializing creating distractions among the cubicles.   Dress code is hoodies, shorts, flip flops, cellphones. Managers will not acknowledge problem areas. Managers distracted by projects. Unable to approach managers outside weekly meetings.  Inconsistent direction. Policies change constantly .  Communication from management is lacking,  reliance on each other for news.  No acknowledgement from management for accomplishments. Apparent favoritism.   Focus on risk issues yet risk managers non responsive on  many issues.  Difficult to get answers.  Staff is held financially responsible for errors which create loss for bank, result in deductions from annual bonus.   Account fees are rarely correct, and involve several layers of review for remediation . Tight clique of managers w upper management.   Unreasonable work load and additional accounts coming our way. Client surveys reveal much discontent and create additional work.  No clerical support available.   Redundant procedures making job a grind.   Stepping stone position for most.

pros: I love my job! The people at Wells Fargo and the culture are a 10 in my book. Especially the ones in my branch . Great benefits, and opportunity!
cons: Systems are frustrating sometimes, and I could make more money at other banks. Which is frustrating. My branch is open 55 hrs a week and on my salary thatâs what I work - it wasnât worth the promotion or time away from my family .

review: Old tech and red tape, but really chill
pros: Wells Fargo is a giant company and experiences vary greatly. The work life balance I experienced there was fantastic.  You could work from home occasionally, there wasn't much pressure to stay late or work through the weekends. Everyone was super happy to be there. The bureaucracy (some people don't like the red tape) did function to ensure that employees were treated fairly.
cons: It's not a technology company. The main applications that the bank depends on were patchwork assembled and maintained by team after team of contractors trying to maintain what had become a rats nest.  There was a decent amount red tape that prevented people doing anything new or innovative.

review: I never had high blood pressure before working here
pros: Benefits are good, however you donât make enough for the copays or meds that you probably need. They also have a decent PTO package, but youâre made to feel guilty for taking it and again, you canât afford to.
cons:
The hiring process is a joke, archaic and bureaucratic. The pay alone deters top talent, and youâre flat out lied to about what youâll realistically make. The scoring metrics that affect your pay are set up to make you fail. You have to depend on incompetent and apathetic fulfillment partners to make a loan go through. But my roleâs pay is adversely affected by their poor performance, but my performance has no negative impacts on their compensation. This leads to a combative and toxic work environment. 

Work life balance is a joke, and this is not a good fit for working parents. Youâre pressured into working overtime every week. Youâre bound to an inbound call schedule that will prohibit you from taking breaks that are required by law, and management constantly expects more production for no benefit to the worker. This schedule is also subject to change daily so you can never effectively plan your day or week. 

Expect to make about $50k a year, and this business is extremely detailed and complex to learn, so thereâs a heavy ramp up period. 

The complex is rodent-infested and often smells like decay. Donât eat at the cafeterias.

The culture and work environment is pretty toxic. The sales people are so underpaid that they are unwilling to play as a team and help each other, management does nothing but track reports. Thereâs no real coaching or career planning opportunities. The whole company agenda is to bring in as much business as possible without having to pay out for it. There is no reason why an employee who brings in $25+ million worth of business annually for a company should have to scrape by to pay their bills.

pros: good benefits, decent pay, good location
cons:
Many of my criticisms of Wells Fargo stem from what appear to be huge gaps in competency and an overall lack of planning across the financial crimes risk management group.  It should be noted that these points apply to Anti-Money Laundering only.

Management has been moving forward with a plan, despite widespread criticism at the investigator level, to move all teams to a 5 days in office/5 days working from home plan.  This plan would be so rigid as to force you to use your own PTO if you were unable to be in the office or work from home on your assigned week.  Our team has repeatedly been misled, beginning with our initial interviews, on the leniency of the company's work from home policy.  As our team has bounced between leaders, each has arbitrarily raised the required minimum days remaining on cases in our queue to prevent us from working remotely.  Leadership has also repeatedly dangled the prospect of across the board promotions to all Financial Crimes Consultant 2 team members to FC 3, however, as this has been in talks for over a year, and we are in yet another hiring freeze, this appears to be just another tall tale.  

There appears to be little to no room for advancement in Philadelphia, as financial crimes compliance is frequently subject to hiring freezes, and they appear to be pushing to remove us physically from the building based on the above working from home plan.

This theme of arbitrary leadership decisions is a problem across all aspects of our work, and is exacerbated by the clear lack of industry knowledge and proper priorities for compliance investigations groups at all levels of management on the East Coast, but particularly at the manager and director level.  Wells Fargo's program requires each and every case to be scrutinized by your direct manager, who often apply their own questionable nitpicks to what should be a streamlined, consistent production-based environment.  Some managers have next to no financial crimes experience, knowledge of company systems, or leadership skills.  If you are used to any autonomy in your investigative work, you will hate it here.  This is the only investigative group I've been a part of where the managers have no cases of their own to complete, and are essentially QR (even though there is an actual QR with much more lenient standards as they service all teams). 

These huge inconsistencies between teams are the result of an overall lack of written policies and procedures I had never encountered in a compliance program before coming to Wells Fargo.  What little written guidance there is is often supplemented by verbal updates from leadership with questionable understanding of the issues at hand, and often are never even added in writing to the compliance manuals.  Teams with the same pay grade, investigative mandates, and case loads are hugely inconsistent across the company to a level I had not though imaginable.  This can mean the difference between one team only having to review a single account for a month time span, with another team for the same referral having to review 20 accounts over a year.  There appears to be an established culture of managers and directors with no real productive casework to do, who are encouraged to add their own anal guidelines for their respective teams down the chain.  Every single policy change I have seen, at the director or manager level, has consisted of them adding more work for us to do, or curtailing our privileges.  It is especially insulting having compliance experience in mature programs and knowing that these changes are never actually the result of guidance stemming from the federal government or an audit, but middle managers seeking to appear more strict and thorough than the next, as they view our teams as another stepping stone to move up.

Philadelphia morale remains low as our teams are again and again subject to rules which we see our colleagues in other regions, lucky enough to be under qualified leadership, not have to deal with.  Management holds us to the quantitative standards of a high volume production environment, and appears unable to create efficient processes to succeed with that level of case work.  Our case load has increased unbelievably in our time, from what was an expected 3 cases completed per day, to what is now 5.  It is impossible to conduct in depth reviews given that volume yet managers constantly push for more to be completed.  We feel that we are always bearing the burden of management's lack of planning which caused this situation, as we are constantly understaffed, and see arbitrary priority level escalations, new monitoring referral sources, and ill-conceived policies be implemented every day.

review: What  you read in the papers is false...it's actually worse.

cons: After 18 years of working here, I am seeing all back office jobs move to countries where the labor is less expensive. The managers responsible for all that you read about are still here, just in different management roles. You really think they're not going to find a way to cheat?  I would not be surprised if we all hear something else within the next 12 months.

The business model is focused on sales, not service. You have to offer products to every customer who comes in. Customers were often frustrated with the pestering. The good, honest, kind employees were pushed out while the aggressive, unethical employees were promoted.
